I was BLOWN AWAY by how easy and delicious this recipe is! They were pillowy soft, deliciously chewy, a nice, neutral flavor, and didn't require me to knead that much at all. I made these without a bread machine following the instructions of the top comment, and like her I made clover rolls instead of crescents. I softened the butter in a rush by putting it on the defrost setting in the microwave for 20 seconds. 10 minutes in an oven at 375 degrees was perfect.

None
text:
So tasty! I don't have a bread machine, so I followed K Praper's directions for the prep, and they turned out great! The rolls themselves were so perfect. The only changes I made (which didn't have an effect on the rolls themselves) were that I rolled ham and swiss in them before setting them to rise the second time and brushed the tops of them with a mixture of 1T spicy mustard, 4-6T butter, 1T poppy seeds, and 3-4T chopped onion before putting them in the oven. SO GOOD! For those of you who had crumbly rolls, that is often an issue with how they were prepared rather than with the ingredients. Not kneading them enough, using poor quality flour, or even letting them rise for too long, can lead to crumbly bread.

These rolls are phenomenal. I first made these 2 years ago when I hosted my first Thanksgiving and they were the only thing we didn't have leftovers of. I now make this recipe frequently with regular dinners. What's great about it is that it doesn't have to be pigeon-holed into rolls. Don't have the time to go through the extra steps of making rolls? Just throw it in your bread machine on a regular bread cycle and it makes a delicious loaf of bread as well. I honestly have made it so many times that way my family forgot that it's actually a roll recipe. I don't change anything about the recipe at all.

userID:
1476363
Display Name:
Cyndi K.
isPro:

followersCount:
1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/316561.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these a few times.  After proofing the yeast in the water with a pinch of sugar I add the yeast and all the other ingredients, except the flour and salt, into my Kitchenaid with the paddle.  Then I add the salt and 3 cups of flour. When it gets thick, I switch to the dough hook and add the rest of the flour just until the dough pulls off the bottom of the bowl. The mixer kneads the dough for about 5 minutes and I simply move the dough to a cutting board, make round rolls and place them on a greased sheet tray. The last time I cut the sugar to 1/4 cup and used half a large cake of fresh yeast.   If you make all dinner sized rolls, it will make 24 good sized round rolls. This time I made 12 dinner rolls and 4 the size of hamburger buns.  I baked at 375ºF. The dinner rolls took 12 minutes and the hamburger buns took 16 minutes... both were golden and beautiful.  I will be using the buns for pulled pork sandwiches.   
Since the only rising time really needed is after the rolls are formed, it is one of the fastest, tastiest, and almost foolproof recipes I have found.  You can easily make them start to finish in 2 hours because they only need to rise once.  Very easy to change it up with less sugar, some finely minced garlic and bits of fresh rosemary too.  You just can't go wrong with these!

text:
These were so good and super easy! No bread machine in this household, nor do I have a fancy Kitchen Aid mixer.  Used a reviewers suggestions to micro the milk and water, add the sugar, then yeast, let sit, mixed all that with a spoon.  Adding the egg, butter and salt, used a regular mixer. Added flour gradually mixing with mixer as well. Let rise for 45 minutes after gently kneading, covering with warm towel. After punching down, pulled about 20 'ball's and put into 2 greased pie plates, spaced apart. Let rise a second time for an hour. Baked at 400 aproximately 10 minutes. So worth it! Thanks for the great recipe!

I make this recipe into a loaf of bread in my bread maker...yummm.  It stay's soft and moist with proper storage for at least 4 days.  If there were more of us in the family I'm sure it wouldn't last 4 days!  I have a 2 pound bread maker and it raises to the very top, so if you have a smaller bread maker you probably need to half or 3/4 the recipe.  I make no adjustments the recipe is great as is.  The only downside it that I haven't experimented on making too many different breads because this one is so good!  See my pictures too.

text:
I'd give this recipe 10 stars if I could.   THANK YOU DONNA!!

I cut the recipe in half since there are only two of us at home; I made the dough in my bread machine (dough cycle).  I rolled the dough into 9 balls and placed them in a greased large pie plate and let them rise for an hour.   I baked them for 25 minutes in a 350 oven; brushed the tops of the rolls with butter and let them cool.   My DH ate 4 of them before dinner.   

The rolls are soft and YUMMY!!!   These are the best rolls I've ever made; this will be my new 'go to recipe'.

text:
These were really tender and flaky, with a nice sweetish buttery flavor. They were a big hit with my family. My picky toddler even ate his green beans in order to get a second one! 
I don't have a bread machine, so I did it in my KitchenAid. I heated up the milk and water in the microwave for a little over a minute, then I put it in my KitchenAid bowl and mixed in the sugar, then the yeast and let it proof 10 minutes. I added the flour a half cup at a time, and it was really sticky so I needed to add an additional 1/2 cup of flour. I kneaded it with the dough-hook for 10 minutes, then let it rise covered in the bowl for 45 min. I then proceeded with the recipe as written,. though I baked them at 375 for 15 minutes. Next time I'll pull them out about 2 minutes earlier than that. 
I'll be adding this to my regular dinner rotation! Thanks for the recipe.

These are wonderful!  I use 100% whole wheat (freshly ground) and they still turn out amazing!  Though I do add a bit more milk because the whole wheat can make it a bit more dry. (I also cut the sugar back by about 50% and use Sucanat, Rapadura, or Honey instead)

userID:
6316618
Display Name:
nerrym
isPro:

followersCount:

6

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Lordy- I can't believe I just baked these up.  Unbelievable- here's what I did since I don't have a bread machine: I mixed 2 1/2 teaspoons yeast, 1/2 warm water and 1 teaspoon sugar. Stir once and left for 6 minutes to proof in warm oven.  Using my Kitchen Aid mixer, I added all of the wet ingredients, then added the proofed yeast and 1 cup of flour at a time, kneading slowly with the dough hook for about 6 minutes total.  I removed the dough, oild the mixer bowl and put it back in, covered the bowl and let it rise for 1 hour 40 minutes.  I then punched the dough down, made 16 balls and placed them in a parchment-lined 9x13 glass dish.  I covered with cling wrap that I sprayed with oil so it didn't stick to the rolls and let it rise for 40 minutes.  I removed the wrap, placed in preheated oven at 350 degrees for 13 minutes.  I did not use the additional 1/4 butter to brush them- I left them alone.  Excellent recipe.  Thanks a million, Donna.

I will have to try to make these again.  I'm not sure what I did wrong, but these flattened out when i put them in the oven :(  Everything I used was new and fresh, so I'm not sure what could have possibly caused that. I'll revisit this recipe again and try again and maybe re-rate it then :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe often... for holiday meals, every day meals, and pitch-in dinners.  They are a hit every single time.  I am often requested to make these rolls.  They are just the right sweetness-not quite as sweet as Hawaiin dinner rolls.  The only difference I have ever done is to make them into round rolls, not crescents.  When I do that I do not add the extra butter on top-and they turn out nice and brown and still very tasty.  Also, I do not always make th 16 rolls it calls for out of one recipe, I often make anywhere from 24-32 rolls with this recipe.  A great recipe to have for any time dinner rolls are needed (or wanted)!

text:
These were great,so light and fluffy! Instead of crescents,i formed the dough into balls,rolled them in melted butter,then let them rise for an hour in 2 round baking pans. My first batch made 23 rolls,and the second made 27. I baked them at 350 for about 15 minutes. They were a hit at Thanksgiving. Home made bread is so much better than store bought. I also put my milk,butter and water together in a measuring cup and nuked it for a minute and 15 seconds before adding it to the bread machine.

text:
These were a big hit at our Thanksgiving dinner. Everyone wanted seconds! I don't have a bread maker so I warmed the milk and water in the microwave for 1 minute 15. Added the yeast. Waited 10 minutes then added everything else (flour 1/2 cup by 1/2 cup) and mixed it all together. Let it sit for like an hour and then punched it down and rolled into 18 rolls. Delicious!

text:
I made this by hand as well.  Kneaded 10 minutes.  Ratio of ingredients was just fine.  I used it to make 9 dinner rolls in a pie plate, and 10 roll-up cinnamon rolls in an 8x11.  Mad a 15" roll, and cut into 1 1/2" slices.  Used the filling recipe from the Cinnabon Clone recipe--mixed teh sugar, butter and cinnamon together and spread it on the dough.  The cinnamon rolls turned out GREAT.  FANTASTIC.  The dinner rolls just OK, and I may have baked them about 3 minutes too long.  I reduced the baking temp of everything to 375.  I think this is a much better recipe for "formed" type rolls, as in the picture, or the cinnamon rolls, but just the balls of dough turned out tough.  I will save to use as my cinnamon roll recipe.

None
text:
I absolutely love this recipe, and I intend to make it whenever I get the craving for homemade bread.
I, like many of the other reviewers, modified this recipe somewhat. I do not have a breadmaker, so I mixed and kneaded the dough in my stand mixer. 
In addition, I made some other changes: I increased the recipe by 1.5 to make 24 rolls instead of 16, although I still only used one packet of yeast and just let it rise a little longer.  To help the yeast rise the additional dough, I substituted 2/3 cup of flour for potato flakes (which yeast love).  The resulting rolls were absolutely perfect!
I would give this recipe 10 stars if I could!!

text:
Finally ... a roll recipe that produces soft delicious rolls.

I used 2 1/2 teaspoons rapid rise yeast -- proofed in warmed water, and added a little extra flour (about 1/8 cup) after kneading for a few minutes,  to get the smooth consistency needed.

I made crescent shaped rolls with half the dough, and even though I didn't do a great job of making them a uniform size - some were at least 25% larger than others - they still baked up nicely in a 375° F oven.

I'll probably try cloverleaf with the rest of the dough.  Although I'm tempted to make some pigs in blanket with the rest in the morning.

Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
I have never been able to make good bread of any kind before, so let me tell you, it is just a great feeling to actually be able to produce rolls that are so wonderful.  These are just fantastic--and easy enough for a novice like me.  

I didn't want to lug out the breadmaker, so I followed some of the suggestions from other ladies who made these babies by hand.  Then I just rolled the dough into little balls (with my history in breadmaking, I wasn't willing to invest too much time).  The balls puffed up like big beautiful bubbles--so cute!  I'm delighted to finally have a go-to dinner roll recipe for family gatherings.  And I can't wait to try the cinnamon rolls... Thank you so much for sharing this recipe!

text:
Oh My Yum!  Made to go with Ham 'n Green Beans last night and they were great. The perfect hint of sweetness that made them extra special. The butter did amazing things to the texture of the inside of the roll.  I let them raise a bit too much and they kind of exploded. Tasted great though.  I had trouble rolling them out big enough and ended up stretching by hand.  Used a pizza cutter for even pieces.  I didn't care for the texture on the outside much...too much flour from the rolling out process.  User error, I'm sure.  I've got a batch raising as "regular" rolls and will egg wash them before baking.  I'll let you know how it turns out.  Keeper for sure though!

text:
I've been using this recipe for several years now and the rolls always turn out great.  My family looks forward to them each holiday!  To make my rolls even softer, I let the dough rest in the bread machine when the cycle completes for about an hour, roll them out, and let them rise for another 2 or 3 hours (if time allows).  You can also make them and roll them out a day ahead of time, wrap them tight with plastic wrap, and refrigerate overnight.  Amazing recipe that could not be any easier!

text:
Great recipe, extremely easy! My first time making rolls and it was easy! I let both batches rise on the counter covered, one on a cookie sheet and the other on a flat board and didn't realize you can't transfer after they rise because then they collapse. So, I had one amazing puffy batch of rolls and one that were good but lacking the fluffiness. So first time bread makers, no transferring after the bread rises :) Tasted great!

text:
These rolls are "Get in My Belly" delicious!  And so much fun to make.  I wasn't sure how long to leave the dough in my breadmachine, but whatever I did worked well.  I followed Annabellee's advice to cut her dough into 36-inch pieces and place 3 pieces into each cup of a 12-cup muffin tin.  After rising for about an hour, I brushed melted butter on top of each roll and sprinkled half with poppy seeds and half with sesame seeds before popping them into the oven.  (I sprayed each muffin cup with cooking spray first, and there was absolutely no problem getting the rolls out.)  Served with beef stew -- perfect for a fall evening.

text:
This is by far one of the best rolls I can possibly imagine. I'm going to try to make this as cinnamon rolls since some of the "clone" recipes aren't all that great. As a dinner roll this is just sweet enough, just soft enough on the inside and just crusty enough on the outside. This recipe is virtually bullet proof. Every time I've failed with it - I was clearly at fault and I could trace my failure. This is one of those recipes where you're better off with the freshest ingredients - good quality butter, fresh milk and eggs - because it's the difference between stupendous rolls and just great ones.

text:
What a great recipe! I have had problems in the past with my rolls staying soft after they cool...but not this recipe! The rolls are perfect, and extremely delicious. I used half bread flour, which helped a bit with the texture...but other than that, made these exactly as written. The one issue I had was with the size...the finished rolls are HUGE. In my opinion, a dinner roll should be a small addition, not an entire meal :) Although these rolls are so good, that I don't think anyone will mind! Next time I make them, however, I'm going to divide the dough into three parts instead of two, and roll it out to 1/4" thickness. I think that this size will be nicer. Thanks for sharing this recipe...it is a winner!!!

Awesome recipe!!!! Thank you so much for sharing with us!! So versatile and yummy! I just found this recipe a few days ago and have made it 3 times. The first 2 times, I halved the recipe for small dinner rolls and the 2nd time for larger rolls to be used for lunches.  With the rolls for lunch, I sauted onions and put on top as they were rising the second time.  Turned out wonderful! Tonight, I shaped into  oblong rolls for oktoberfest sausages, again-wonderful. I will definitely be using this recipe at our trailer for lots of bbqs and trying many variations!  I would rate this as 10+ stars if able!!!! Thanks again for sharing!

text:
Very yummy!  I do not own a bread machine, but have made enough pizza dough, so just mixed together the water, milk, sugar and yeast and let proof 10-15 mins.  Then added my egg, salt, butter and flour (bit at a time).  I decided to roll little balls of dough and bake in pie pans...ended up with 27 (9 per pie pan).  Baked at 350 for about 15 mins.  I was expecting a lighter more airy dinner roll, but as others mentioned, these were a bit more dense, but not in a bad way, just different than I expected.  Regardless, they were still great!

text:
these were heavenly!  I've made these several times.  I have always made them as rolls and not as cresents.  The first few times I didn't put butter in them before forming as rolls.  For Thanksgiving I put butter in them and then formed a ball.  Let them rise per the directions, then baked.  When I removed them from the oven I rubbed cold butter on the top so it would melt a bit.  I made 4 batches of these and my rolls were gone before anything else at the table!  Make sure you put butter in there for the second rising, it make a huge difference!  Also, I didn't have a bread machine, so when I mix the butter and egg into the dough I have to use a hand mixer or it'll never get incorporated enough.  Other people have commented on how to proof the dough, etc in other reviews so I won't go into that in here.  Thanks for the recipe Donna!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Brilliant and fool proof!  I literally made these while I was busy making dinner (as a test for Thanksgiving.)  Didn't want to spend much time on them so after proofing the yeast/milk/water/sugar I mixed/kneaded that with the rest of the ingredients in my KitchenAid, let it rise for about 45 minutes.  Rolled into balls and tossed into PAM sprayed, pyrex pie plates.  Let them rise for an hour, brushed with melted butter and baked.  Great results.  Seems like everyone has a different temp/time for these.  Use an oven thermometer set to 400 and keep an eye on them.  Mine took about 18 minutes.

This is an awesome recipe! My first time making bread by hand that turned out delicious. I dont have a bread maker so this is what I did - I combined the yeast and milk, combined the other ingredients and sifted the flour before adding it. I let the dough rise over the heat of the warming oven. I then rolled out a portion of the dough, buttered it and formed dough balls to rise over the oven. With the other half of the dough I made cinnamon rolls. My husband said that the rolls were better than cinnabon! Thank you for this recipe!

text:
These were really... REALLY good! I followed the recipe exactly but made it by hand.. I have a bread machine but I like kneading it b/c I get a better feel for when the dough is ready and for how much flour to use that way. I mixed 3 cups of the flour in my mixture and the last cup I used to knead the dough in..I kept kneading till the dough wasn't sticky anymore. (about 7 mins) I probably ended up using alittle more than the 3 3/4 cups of flour doing it that way but it still came out perfect. And I took others advice and put 3 small balls in a muffin tin, let it rise and baked it like that and the rolls were BEAUTIFUL! All the kids loved them and told me to make them like that from now on.  THANK YOU!

country:
None
text:
These never fail to make absolutely delicious dinner rolls that receive many compliments.  I do the proofing/dough process by hand and let the dough rise for 1 hour in each rise cycle.  I use whole wheat flour for 1-3/4 cups of the flour amount.  I have tried the rolls both by rolling the dough out flat and rolling up, and simply dividing the dough into pieces and allowing to rise.  The rolls are far superior (extra light and flaky) with the extra few minutes to roll the dough flat.  I make 16 rolls - divide the dough into four pieces, rolling out each piece into a rectangle and rolling up then cutting into four pieces.

text:
Very yummy!  I don't have a bread machine so I made the rolls the old fashioned way.  The only change I made was to substitute 1 1/2c of the flour with whole wheat flour.  Also, I rolled the dough into two squares, cut each one into 1" strips and layered the strips in groups of five.  Then, I cut the layered strips in 2" sections with dental floss and put them into muffin pans.  Turned out absolutely fab!  Thanks for the great recipe, Donna!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great, basic roll recipe.  I like that it uses all purpose flour because I can never seem to remember to buy bread flour.  It's also nice to not need one more item to take up space in my already small home.  I don't use a bread machine when I make this.  I set the eggs out for a couple hours to warm.  Then I place the warm water, warm milk and sugar in a bowl.  Dissolve the sugar and then add the yeast and let it proof.  Then I add the eggs, butter, salt and flour.  Mix well with my hands and put it in a greased bowl, turning once to coat, then cover with towel and let it rise.  After one hour (or after it doubles) I punch it down and roll into three small balls per muffin slot and make cloverleaf rolls.  I let them rise another hour and then bake.  Yummy and they go really fast around here so I bake a double batch which gives me approx. 48 cloverleaf rolls.

text:
Great, versatile dough recipe.  I made the rolls as written with half the recipe the first night, and I had to make my son stop eating them.  I formed the other half into smaller dough balls and put them in the fridge.  I melted some butter in the bottom of a glass pie plate two mornings later then sprinkled that with some brown sugar, chopped pecans, and cinnamon, then put the dough balls on top.  I baked them, then flipped the pie dish over onto a plate after taking them out of the oven - voila, sticky buns.  My kids were over the moon with those!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These rolls are simply amazing.  They come out perfect every single time.   I do not have a bread machine, so I prep the yeast in the warm water and about a Tbsp of the sugar.  Then, I warm the milk and butter to about the same temp in the microwave.  When the yeast is frothy, I stir in the warmed milk, butter, egg, remaining sugar, and salt.  I then add in the flour, one cup at a time, kneading in the last cup by hand. Form into a ball, cover, and place in a warm spot until the dough has doubled.  It takes about an hour.  Then, simply proceed with the recipe from Step 2.    I make these rolls at least twice a month.  My kids inhale them, expecially when I serve them with gravy or honey-butter.  The crescent shape is worth the extra effort, as it adds to the texture and charm of this wonderful, soft bread.  Going to try them as cinnamon rolls next.  Thank you for this 5 star recipe!

text:
We just love these!  After making a few batches, I decided that to get the perfect size for dinner crescents, roll to 12 inch circle, cut into quarters then cut each quarter into three slices so you have a total of 12 from each dough half.  You'll end up with a big basket of 24 not-too-big, not-too-small delicious crescent rolls.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
these rolls tasted pretty good. they had a nice flavor, although they were a little tough the next day. i added about 2 tbsp of clover honey just because i love honey, but i'm sure they are good w/o that addition. i didn't want to use my breadmaker so i did it by hand. mix the water, a pinch of sugar, and yeast together (i just put them in a measuring cup) and let it proof, about ten minutes or until it gets bubbly. then just mix all the ingredients together (i usually use a wooden spoon), adding the flour last, until you have a sticky dough. knead on a floured surface until you get a smooth ball, place in a greased bowl, cover with a clean kitchen towel or greased plastic wrap, and let it rise about 2 hrs in a warm place. then follow the directions from there. my apt was kind of cool, so it didn't rise really well the first time, but after i shaped them (i just cut into squares, i had about 24 rolls), buttered the tops, and let them rise again while i drove to mom's in the warm car (about 45 minute drive), they about doubled in size. they cooked for about 20 minutes and everyone loved them. i thought they tasted good, seemed just a tad dry. i may add a little more butter or less flour next time. otherwise, this is a great recipe. thanks for sharing.

text:
This was great and very easy to make! I do not have a bread machine so instead I did it by hand. First I let the milk, water, sugar, and yeast sit together for about 20 minutes to grow. I then added everything else and kneaded for a while. After it rose about an hour I formed 12 balls and put them in a 9x13 pan to rise again. After 45 min, I baked for 15 minutes. They were great! I'll definitely make them again! Maybe next time I'll use two pans though - the 12 rolls were huge!

text:
I ended up making these twice today (Christmas Day) the first time I just didn't like the results. (Good thing I started at 4 am)  They were ok but just not up to my standards of what I normally make for Dinner Rolls. So since it got such great reviews I decided to try again.  The second time  I made a few changes...instead of adding the 1/4 cup of butter at the end I changed that to shortening and actually added it into the dough in the bread machine.  I had to add another 1/4 cup of flour because after I added it the dough was just way to sticky (which I knew it was going to be) After I made these changes though the rolls were perfect.  They were light, fluffy, had a nice bread taste, and turned out beautifully.  Instead of rolling them out I put 3 small balls each into each muffin pan to make Clover Leaf Rolls.  They were really good. The only person who didn't like them was my cousin and I think that is just because he is used to my grandma's recipe....although he did eat 5 of them so he couldn't have hated them that much.

2171376
Display Name:
Tahna

photo:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were pretty good - the texture was light and fluffy.  I am giving them a 4 instead of a 5 because they could have had a little more flavor - 

I made these without a bread machine-proofed the yeast per the instructions on the yeast jar (20 minutes) (used one serving of yeast); warmed milk and butter in pan then added it to the yeast proof (make sure it's not too hot or you will kill the yeast), added sugar, salt/flour 1/2 C. at a time mixed in Kitchenaid with dough hook.  Added exactly 3 3/4 C. all purpose flour (if you dip your cup you will get too much flour).  Let rise 1 hour, punched down, divided and made clover leaf rolls, let rise 1 hour baked on 375 for 12 minutes.

Recipe made 12 rolls, plus enough left over for 2 small cinnamon rolls.

text:
YUMMMYY!! Hot outa the oven these rolls almost didn't make it to the table.  Next time I might add a squeak less sugar but other than that these were fabulous.  I took half the batch and rolled into balls and baked in muffin tins.  YUMMY!!
The second batch I rolled out and rubbed 1/3 cup softened butter and mixed 1 cup brown sugar with 3 tsps cinnamon and sprinkled all over the butter.  Rolled that up and cut into buns and let rise for awhile and baked 375 for 20 minutes.  I iced those with a cream cheese icing and WOW how delicious.  Great base recipe for so many yummy things.
Don't pass it up...you'll be missing out.

text:
Awesome recipe-

I used the stand mixer-I did have to add a bit more flour (about 1/4+ C) maybe because of humidity? I didnt proof the yeast, I just added all dry ingredients, heated milk/water/melted butter, tempered the egg and mixed the whole thing with the stand mixer.
 The dough seemed a bit sticky when I put it in a greased bowl to rise, but it was just fine. I let it rise a few hours, punched it down and formed it (half for clover rolls, half for cinnamon rolls) let rise and baked at 375* for 12 minutes.
 Tastes wonderful-bakes up light and airy-Really yummy.
Thanks for sharing this recipe.

I think these were amazing. All I did different was make them into 15 buns and then baked them in a 13 by 9 pan. They were incredibly soft and the dough was sooo easy to work with..not sticky at all. country:
None
text:
OK folks - I made the dough last night and a little FYI - if you want to make a loaf - do NOT let it rise for the full hour. It "poofed" wonderfully but sank as soon as I set it on the counter. (I let my bread rise in a preheated & turned off oven)  Not one to waste - I baked it (350 for 20 mins)  When it came out it was heavenly.  Light, airy & just plain good. Another little FYI - do not put a "not quite cooled yet" loaf in a plastic bag & into the fridge.  This morning it was quite heavy & dense.  Will try again and watch as it rises and maybe separate into 2 pans.  But the taste was still as awesome.

text:
Besides the fact that I've always these croissants (I was expecting something more like buns, though once I read the recipe I realized that wasn't the case) these are great!  The dough is soft and manageable for rolling and the bread machine does the hard work.  I even screwed up by heating the oven too much so that when I put the rolls in to rise they actually baked slightly, and then halfway through baking the second batch someone turned off the oven...and they were STILL good!  So, give them a try. 

Note: Many bread machines include the First Rise in their Dough cycle in case anyone is confused.

Display Name:
Steph

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you attempt to bake this recipe, please do! Do not let the bad reviews influence you to try these out! :) Everyone who knows how to handle yeast do, will have no problems to get them fluffy and tasty. I have no bread machine, I bake my breads in the oven, so I made the dough the "traditional" way. (Let yeast activate in warm liquids with a tbsp of sugar till foamy then add the rest of the ingredients), I let the dough rise for about 45 minutes and made the punch down finger test, the dough was easy to work with. Many said they needed incredible extra amounts of flour, unless the recipe has been modified after these reviews I cannot confirm. I baked them at 375°F and lowered the temp to 350°F for the last 5 minutes. Also, when I put them in, I gave them a little steam which I let out of the oven after 5 minutes. Thanks, for this great recipe!

Edit: I froze a few, since I had made double of the recipe. I took them out right before dinner and thawed them in the microwave and taste just as good as just out of the oven.

text:
Wonderful! We loved them ! Idid alter the recipe, used SELF RISING FLOUR (it's what I had on hand), and 2 fresh eggs, and no salt. I had to adjust with a little more flour as the dough mixed, I guess the second egg was a little much..lol. I did a quick rise at 200 degrees for 5 minutes, then straight into 20 minutes baking at 350. Note: I did not use quick rise yeast. The last two minutes I poured melted butter over rolls, and finished baking, beautiful rolls. Delicious! Going to be my new roll recipe. thanks again!

text:
AMAZING!!! I just made these and they are so soft and buttery. When I made these I didn't have any active dry yeast, so I used bread machine yeast and they turned out wonderfully. The only thing with using bread machine yeast instead of active dry yeast is that you have to use less. (ex.one .25 ounce package of active dry yeast is equal to 2 1/4 teaspoons, which I had to reduce by 25%, so I ended up using 1 and a heaping 1/2 teaspoon of bread machine yeast.)  I also made half of the batch into cinnamon rolls by mixing 1/2 a cup of brown sugar and 1 tsp of cinnamon.
Review:
Rating:
5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
No bread machine so I followed the directions given in an early comment for soaking the yeast with the sugar etc. Directions worked well but I would have let the dough rise another 30 mins. to an hour next time. When I checked the dough rise after 30 mins I was afraid it wouldn't-- it was still very firm. Dough did rise a lot in the last 30 mins though and I think the bread may have come out fluffier if left to proof longer but that's just an opinion at this point.

The recipe is good and seems trustworthy, if a little bland and yeasty. Was also a bit more crusty than I expected, a heavier, denser bread. Made cinnamon rolls with a part of the batch and made a mess when the filling ran out everywhere, but the cinnamon variety was a little better imo, probably due to adding flavor to the dough, which I am going to try doing myself next time.

Delicious!  I used this recipe and added sticks of pepperoni for delicious AWARD WINNING pepperoni rolls.  It was very easy to put the ingredients in my bread machine to mix while I cut the pepperoni into sticks.  By the time I was done, so was the kneading. These rolls are fabulous as written. I've made them so many times, with many variations. I have a breadmaker, but I prefer to make these the traditional way. The dough is very easy to work with. The taste is amazing. I've used a few variations over the years; Such as all water and no milk. I've replaced the egg with oil. I've added herbs and spices into the butter mixture. And as the recipes states, wonderful for cinnamon AND orange sweet rolls. This is a great starting point for making amazing rolls your family will love. And remember: It's just food. Play with it!

text:
These are the bomb!  Made a test batch for hubby before launching into roll production for Thanksgiving.  Melt in your mouth delish! Followed the recipe exactly, and they turned out perfectly! Thanks for making me look good with the relatives! (Now I am making them for Christmas as well!) 
If the batch is too large for rolls, you can use half to make Cinnamon rolls, which turned out great also. 
Followed another reviewer's suggestion to make balls for rolls (not risen) and freeze for later. When you are ready to use them, put them out to thaw at room temperature and rise until about double in size, baking at 350 until done.

text:
mostly this was very good, but I too could not get them to raise, I did what my mom used to do I put them in the oven that I had warmed first,then turned the oven off. that did it, they rose. I guess if your not in a real warm area they do not raise well. You could also put them on top of stove while you are cooking in the oven that will get them to rise also. I think they tasted fine but not the best rolls I ever had like some people thought.

text:
These could not be easier. I made them with my father-in-law's favorite pot roast dinner. I did the cloverleaf thing too -- rolled into three balls per muffin tin and they looked downright professional. I followed the advice of the first reviewer under the recipe and mixed the milk and ALL THE SUGAR and the water in the bowl. At first I just mixed in the 2tsps the packet of yeast calls for and it didn't foam but when I added the rest of the sugar from the recipe -- it foamed right up. I buttered the insides of the muffin tins and I brushed melted butter on top of the rolls before baking. I also lowered my oven temp to 350 as that first review suggests. These were very good. The next day my mom stopped by and ate two. She liked them so much that she took home the recipe! This is a keeper and these rolls will be on the Thanksgiving dinner table this year.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried numerous roll recipes over the years.  This recipe is the best, by far.  My family loves sweet rolls, and these were perfect.  I wouldn't change a thing!  I do not own a bread machine, but these were easy enough to make by hand.  I dissolved the yeast in warm water.  Meanwhile, I scalded the milk, melted the butter in the hot milk, and let the mixture cool.  I whisked in the egg when the milk was cool enough not to scramble it.  I mixed the dry ingredients and added to the wet ingredients, a little at a time.  I kneaded the dough for 6 to 8 minutes, placed it in a greased bowl to rise, and covered it with a cloth.  After about an hour in my warm kitchen, I punched the dough down and shaped it into 20 rolls, which fit nicely into a greased 13x9 pan.  At last!  The perfect roll recipe for my family

text:
The first batch I followed the recipe and I liked it, but the second time I added one egg and another 1/4 cup sugar. Tied them into knotted rolls. Whisked one egg white and a Tbs cold water then brushed tops before cooking. These were a hit! The best dinner rolls I have ever had. My family loved them.

text:
I was really disappointed because these started out great.  I didn't use a bread machine but started the yeast in the water,milk,sugar and then let the dough rise for 45 minutes.  Everything was fine at this point, nice rise etc, but then from here...it all went downhill.  Rolled into crescents, let sit for another hour....no rise at all.  Left alone for another 30 minutes...nothing.  Tried baking a few anyways but turned out heavy, dense and way too sweet.  Not my cup of tea for dinner rolls...

text:
I'm actually shocked that this turned out! I don't have a bread machine so I did it the traditional way and I used whole milk because that's what I had. I think the key is to leave the dough slightly sticky and let them rise, rise, rise both times! I only baked for about 18 minutes. I basted with melted butter before the second rise and as soon as they came out of the oven. Yum!

text:
I adore this recipe.  I've been using it for several months now to make our loaves of bread.  After 3.5 years of trying to find the perfect bread recipe, this was it.  It tastes a lot like store bought bread, but it's healthier and cheaper!  For my son, who is on a casein-free diet, I do sub the cows milk for almond milk and I use coconut oil instead of butter.  I also use unbleached white flour in place of the all-purpose and sometimes, when I'm feeling some health convictions, I'll swap out half the white flour for wheat.  I should do it more often, but I am just not a fan of whole wheat.  :o  This recipe has been perfect for my family!  Thank you for posting it!

country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe. made a few changes however, since I don't have a bread machine. Combined all dry ingredients and added the wet ones to it. And instead of oil, used melted vegetable shortening. Guess it came out even softer because of that alteration. After combining all ingredients i rolled out the dough onto a well floured surface since the dough was quite sticky, kept adding flour until i had a soft, smooth and stretchy dough. Let it rise in a greased bowl, covered with a warm damp cloth until doubled in size, about 45mins. Rolled out and cut wedge shape then rolled like a croissant. Perfect recipe!!!! Thanks

text:
Wow... this recipe is just perfect. I was too lazy to pull out my bread machine, so I did this all by hand. It took a lot longer than expected to rise, because I was impatient waiting for the yeast to foam, but the rolls were done in about 2.5 hours, and were fluffy and delicious. The only change I would make is to not use sweet cream butter, but instead use salted butter, as it wasn't salty enough to balance out the sweet.

With such high praise, I made these for Thanksgiving without a trial run first. We all agree with the 5 star review and if there were more stars...well these would receive the max. text:
My Mom has made this recipe every Thanksgiving that I can remember, now I do. Usually in a double or even triple batch as my sibs and I usually ate them like candy, even before the turkey was on the table. We always cook them at 400 degrees, just under 10 minutes, until lightly golden brown. Then after sliding them onto a cooling rack, brush with butter while still hot. It is essential the they are still soft and a moist on the inside and they will last for days if there are leftovers. PERFECT for leftover turkey sandwiches too!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this was my first experience in breadmaking. I don't have a bread machine, so I followed the advice to dissolve the yeast with a TBSP of sugar in the warm water, and while it proofed, heated the milk, then added the butter and sugar to the warm milk, added it to the yeast stuff and the egg, and mixed the flour in a bit at a time. I got the best sandwich rolls for my efforts. I did substitute 1 3/4 cups of the flour for strong brown bread flour and reduced the sugar. The 1st batch, I made 8 large rolls. Since then, I've made cinnamon rolls with half the dough (baked 10 min at 350 F) and a loaf with the other half (baked another 10 minutes after taking the cinnamon rolls out). All have met with rave reviews. The loaf holds up well in the toaster & makes great sandwiches. I may never purchase bread again!

userID:

Display Name:
MrsHollowell
isPro:

16

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4316723.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I do not have a bread machine, I used my kitchen aid stand mixer with the hook attachment mixed the warm water, milk, and sugar stirred with a spoon and then added the yeast, let it foam for 12 minutes added salt, eggs, butter then flour 1 cup at a time and scraped the bowl a lot to get all the flour incorporated. Plopped it onto my floured counter kneaded it a few times then oiled the bowl put it back in and covered with plastic wrap let it sit in the warm kitchen for 45 minutes, punched it down and divided it into 16 balls sprayed them with non-stick spray and put plastic wrap on top let them rise for another 45mins then spread them with butter baked at 375 for 11 minutes and let cool on a wire wrack and they are light and soft.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These rolls are fantastic. You don't need a bread maker either, just follow a standard bread making method of combining the liquids with the sugar in the bowl with yeast. Allow to foam for 15 mins and then add rest of ingredients, lastly gradually add the flour until a soft dough is achieved. Let rise 30 mins, knead, roll and make buns as per recipe. Allow to rise 1 hour, back at 200C for 10-15 mins until golden brown.    I even stuffed up and used self-raising flour instead of plain flour and they still came out fantastic!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
FANTASTIC sweet bread dough!  I use half unbleached flour and half wheat flour and add a little extra sugar --- no bread machine -- all by hand.  I use this dough to make my "famous" pepperoni rolls -- I weigh out approximately 1 oz portions of dough, press flat  into an oval with my fingers, lay out a row of 5 slices of pepperoni, then roll up, tucking in the ends, and bake them seam side down after egg-washing until golden brown.  The combination of sweet dough with the spicy pepperoni is out of this world (always eat warmed in the microwave)!!!  But I ALWAYS save some of the dough to make my son some cinnamon rolls.  He LOVES them! I tie some dough into a little knot, spray with "I Can't Believe It's Not Butter," and generously dip in a mixture of cinnamon and sugar... no icing necessary with this dough.    THANK you for this recipe that I will use FOR LIFE!!!

text:
This is now my official rolls recipe for nice holiday dinners!  PERFECT!  Makes great cinnamon rolls too.   I love how soft and buttery these are.   I throw all the stuff into my kitchenaid, knead with dough hook, and then I divide into 16 sections (after rising) and make them a gentle knot...brush with butter....then bake.  The recipe takes some time to rise so give it ample time...but wonderfully light and to die for!!!

Great! Used 2 cups AP, 13/4 cup whole wheat flour. I'd like to try it with bread flour instead of AP. I'm not set that these are "the" rolls I will make, but they are definitely good! :) **UPDATE** I froze these rolls individually (wrapped in tin foil then put in a giant zip loc bag) to have on hand in a pinch. I turned some of them into garlic bread to add to my husband's meals, and some for sandwhiches. Very good!!

text:
ok I am a guy and I was able to do this and they turned out delicious. 10 minutes was way too long to be in the oven but still edible. Somebody gave us the bread machine we have and I have no instruction manual so this is pretty much a grantee that it will turn out for any machine every time: first put the warm water and milk, mix the sugar then the yeast. Let it sit for 15 mins. Then add the rest of the ingredients. This way it always rises.

country:
None
text:
Absolutely wonderful dinner rolls!!  I made this recipe using my bread machine and the dough turned out perfect.  I did use a spoon to drop in flour into measuring cup so I didn't use too much flour (so the bread would rise properly).  I baked half the recipe and froze the other half.  I decided to make round dinner rolls.  To freeze the rolls I placed the round rolls on a flat surface in the freezer and allowed them to freeze.  Then I transfered them into a freezer safe container until ready to use.  Take rolls from freezer and allow to thaw and double in size.  Then bake.  I did bake the rolls at 350 degrees for about 10 minutes.

city:

country:

text:
This is a keeper. The texture and flavor of these was as if they were bought from the local bakery and it was so easy. I made the dough two days ahead of Thanksgiving for the first time (without a bread machine) and refrigerated it.  I let the dough come to about room temperature and then formed balls instead of cutting and rolling it and I eliminated the second part of butter.  I then put them in 2 round cake pans and let them rise for about an hour then baked them for the same time and temp the recipe calls for.  We absolutely loved them.  I cannot believe I finally found a roll recipe I can make from scratch and be proud to serve them to guests.  Thanks Donna my search for the perfect roll recipe is over!

text:
This recipe is very versatile and extemely forgiving!  I have made it several times now, adding different things such as herbs and/or cheese, rolled it into a variety of shapes and even had my bread machine lose a paddle and forget the cycle while making it, so it had to be removed and finished being kneaded by hand.  It tastes just as good with whole wheat as it does with white flour.  My mother, who trained as a chef, and always finds something wrong with anything I make, had nothing to say beyond: "Mmmmmm."  And then she ate three.  Thank you so much for such a great recipe!  I don't buy rolls anymore, since it only takes a trice to make these :)

text:
I made this recipe today and this was by far the best roll recipe I have tried to date.  I made it precisely as is even weighing my flour.  I thought that the dough was initially too wet however I just let the bread machine finish its cycle and the dough was perfect.  I lightly patted it out into a rectangle then cut into squares using a pizza cutter like a famous steakhouse.  I brushed them with melted butter before and after baking.  They were perfect!  Light, airy, slightly sweet and buttery.  I will keep this as my go to roll recipe!!!! Yum!

text:
These are delish!! I used bread flour instead of all-purpose, and proofed the yeast with the water and sugar in the bread machine for 15 minutes. The first time I made them into clover-leaf rolls, the ones I'm making now I'll just put into a 9x13. The crescents seem like too much work. After forming, I let them rise in the oven, after heating it to 170 which is the lowest mine goes. I cover them with oiled wax paper and let them rise 1-1 1/2 hrs. I haven't had a problem with sticky dough or them not rising, but I have had to through out the yeast and start that again. If your yeast is no good, you'll end up with biscuits instead of rolls.*Update*I made them tonight as stated, with AP flour and they still turned out wonderful. Formed them into 16 dinner rolls to use for Super Bowl Bites.

text:
WOW! Perfect- light, soft, sweet, and addictive. I brushed mine with a mixture of cream, butter, and sugar while they were baking and it made the top sweet and shiny but still soft. I rolled these into balls and they took about 10 minutes longer to bake than the recipe said. I sifted the flour and used a tad more yeast than called for (because it had been sitting in the cupboard for a while and I wasn't sure about its freshness.) I think that contributed to the rolls being so feather-light. They had the perfect amount of sweetness and were so tender! My husband freaked out. I will keep this recipe forever. Yum, yum, YUM!  The total time it took to make these was three and a half hours- I just dumped all the items in the bread maker, 1 hour and 50 minutes in the breadmaker, 1 hour to rise, and then 25 minutes to bake. The actual hands-on time is extremely small, though- these were easy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent rolls! Instead of using a bread machine, I use my mixer.  Microwave milk and water for 1 minute and 15 seconds, dissolve sugar in warm water/milk mixture, add yeast and wait till it foams (about 5 minutes).  Then I add salt, butter and flour, mix, and knead in the mixer with dough hook for 7 minutes.  Let rise covered in a warm oven for about an hour.  I divide into 24 balls, let rise for another 30 minutes, brush with milk, and bake on my airbake cookie sheet at 400 for 15 minutes.  The rolls are so good especially while they are warm.  My husband and I can eat the entire batch.  So much for dieting, these are too good to resist! Definitely a keeper.

Oh my word, these reviews do not lie!!!  These are bad bad bad!  Thankfully I immediately put half the batch in the freezer since there were only 4 of us.  I'm so glad I did because otherwise I probably would have polished off about 6 of them myself for dinner!    My only suggestion is that I thought the temp was a little high. Tonight I cooked the rest of them that I had frozen and forgot to use parchment paper and the bottoms got burned.  So...either use parchment and lay foil over them near the end if need be, or lower the temp a tad and cook a little longer.  These are definitely a KEEPER!!!

Display Name:

text:
I just baked these for Thanksgiving dinner for a big crowd at my house and received RAVE reviews for these DELICIOUS rolls. These are HANDS DOWN the best dinner rolls I have ever tasted, and definitley DEFINITELY the best I have ever baked myself..and I'm a skilled bread baker. These have absolutely the most wonderful taste and best texture..you cannot go wrong with this recipe. I never would have thought a recipe that sounded this simple could turn out rolls so delectable! I typically look for more complicated roll recipes, only to be disappointed.  These rose PERFECTLY, baked perfectly, and eveyone seemed to want to only eat the rolls this year! I doubled the recipe and used 3 pkgs of yeast (1 1/2 times the recipe). I would advise using all the water and then add only as much flour as you need to make the dough elastic. I wound up using close to 1 c less flour for each batch.  I let the dough rise for a little more than an hour and used quick rise yeast. Also, I don't have a bread machine anymore, so I just warmed the milk & water, added the sugar and the yeast and let sit until foamy (abt 10 mins). Then added everything else, adding the flour last 1 c at a time. Covered with a damp dish towel and let rise. I rolled them into small balls and baked 2 balls together in muffin pans. FABULOUS and EASY!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-12-01T15:04:22.2
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
3183901
Display Name:
BGChef
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
8
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/223436.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really don't write reviews unless something is really amazing or really terrible. These rolls are the former. For those like me who don't have a bread machine and/or like to bake the traditional way, I suggest you follow 'K PRAPER's instructions (1st review on the recipe page). Just to be safe, I also reduced the temp to 375 like many others suggested and baked for 14-15 mins. I made balls instead of cresents. They came out PERFECT and I didn't even use exact measurements; just eyeballed everything because I was in a hurry. They were just as good the next day -- not hard or stale at ALL. Above all, this recipe is sooo quick and easy.

I have the following advice for those who said the rolls are too dense: 1. Be sure to sift the flour, this is an often overlooked crucial step in baking, 2. After you've added the initial 3 cups, add the rest a little at a time and stop when the dough is no longer sticky. You may not end up needing all the flour. I only ended up using about 3 1/4 cups. 3. You MUST let it rise TWICE -- once before rolling out the dough, and then another 45 mins - 1 hour (minimum) after you have formed your rolls. 5. Don't serve immediately. As much as I love em nice and hot out of the oven, they need time to settle so give it a few mins.

dateLastModified:
2008-11-29T11:29:31.76
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
2622862
Display Name:
Cathy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
96
favoritesCount:
151
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6042649.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I mixed the water and milk, heated it to 110 degrees in the microwave, stirred in the sugar until it dissolved, then stirred in 2.5 teaspoons of quick rise yeast from a jar. After it got foamy (about 10 minutes), I poured it in the bowl of my Kitchen Aid stand mixer and added the egg, butter (salted), and ½ teaspoon salt. Next I added 1 cup of whole wheat flour and 2 cups of bread flour a half cup at a time, mixing with the dough hook attachment until a soft, yet slightly tacky dough formed. Then I let the mixer knead the dough on low for about 4 minutes. Next I removed the dough hook, formed the dough into a ball, sprayed the dough and inside of the bowl with cooking spray, covered the bowl with the dough inside of it with plastic wrap, and let the dough rise for about 45 minutes. Then I removed the plastic wrap, punched down the dough, divided it into 18 balls (1.7 ounces each), evenly distributed them among two lined 9-inch round cake pans, covered the pans with plastic wrap, let the dough rise for another 45 minutes until the sides of the dough balls started to touch, removed the plastic wrap, then baked for 15 minutes at 350 degrees.

country:
None
text:
So I made this dough for a second time and used it to make cinnamon rolls.  I rolled the dough out, spread with butter and sprinkled with 1 1/4 cup brown and 4 t. cinnamon, rolled it up and cut it with dental floss.  On 1/3 I also sprinkled raisins.  They rose for 1 hour and then baked at 350 for ~12 minutes.  I made a frosting by combining:  6 oz cream cheese, 6 T. butter, 2 t. vanilla, and 2 1/2 cups powdered sugar.  They were fantastic.  My husband took a bunch to work and got rave reviews.  Super easy.  Next time I'll try to make the cinnamon filling more gooey, but they were awesome as is.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
For Memorial Day, I thought I would make rolls and dessert in one step. I split the dough in half when it came out of the bread machine. The first half I made into 12 of the crescent rolls, baking for 11 minutes. The second half I rolled into a rectangle, spread a mixture of 1 cup brown sugar, 2/3 cup melted butter, and 2 teaspoons cinnamon on top, then rolled up and sliced into cinnamon rolls. The rolls took 17 minutes to bake in a round cake pan. I inverted the pan onto a pie plate and frosted with a basic powdered sugar, butter,, vanilla, and milk frosting. The family loves them! They said they were the best cinnamon rolls they ever had.

text:
OUTSTANDING! I made these this weekend in my kitchen aid, and the results were a ligth fluffy, sweet roll. The flavor reminds me of potato rolls. Normally I have rolls let over, but not this time my family have already plained out Sunday dinner which will include these rolls. I just mixed all the wet ingredients together except for the water, yeast and 1/2 teaspoon of sugar which I proofed my yeast in, and added the flour..yes the dough is sticky and i used a little more than the 3 3/4 cups listed in the recipe, but i only added extra flour a tablespoon at a time until i was able to handle the dough but still a little sticky. I will Never look for another bread recipe!!!!

text:
I have already made these rolls twice this week.  They have been a really big hit.  I don't have a bread maker so I just mixed the ingredients in my Kitchen Aid stand mixer and then on a floured counter top kneaded the dough until it was smooth.  After letting it rise for about an hour in an oiled bowl, I followed the rest of the recipe and shaped the rolls.  They rose again and baked up so soft and delicious.  I'm sure I will make these many more times (probably just in the next couple of weeks!!).

text:
These are wonderful!  I needed a recipe for dinner rolls for a family Easter party and these are perfect.  I cooked mine in a 13x9 pan because I like the soft sides.  

I also turned some into Easter rolls.  You roll dough around a marshmellow, brush with butter and lightly sprinkle with cinnamon and sugar.  Bake for the same amount of time.  They cook up hollow or empty like Christ's tomb.

Well this was my first time making bread, so I am pretty darn happy with myself and those rolls!  I do not have a breadmaker, so I combined the wet ingredients with the yeast (as another reviewer suggested) and then mixed in the rest of ingredients and then kneaded the dough by hand.  Not sure what happened, but I did not need to let the dough rise for longer than 15 minutes the second time - they were already huge!  Next time I might add a little more sugar for a tad more flavor, but these were yumm-o!  Thank you so much for this recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These rolls are excellent.  I have made it a few times and tried different things.  I suggest following the recipe.  I added some honey and couldn't tell the difference.  I also tried making it in the bread machine and in a mixer.  The bread machine batch were noticably fluffier.  I also tried making as cresents, in a muffin tin and in a casserole dish.  I preferred the muffin tin and casserole dish.  I also seperated them into 24 pieces, rolled them into balls, put them in the tin or dish, then let rise.  They only needed to rise for 30 minutes.  I then heavily brushed on the butter.  Cooking time seemed about the same.  The rolls in the tin did brown faster on the bottom, so maybe lower the temperature if you do it that way.  Everyone raved and thought they were from a bakery.

country:
None
text:
WONDERFUL RECIPE! and very versatile too! I made it 3 times so far - and once was for a church potluck - people loved it! I changed a few things... oil instead of butter, and 1 cup milk instead of 1/2 water... I also found the dough too dry at 1st so added about 1/3cup water.  I used 2tsp bread machine yeast instead of the packet... a lot cheaper. I also didn't use that last bit of butter for brushing on top. This recipe is EASILY adapted to whole wheat.. one of the times I substituted 3 3/4 cup whole wheat flour and 1 tbsp vital wheat gluten flour... This will be my basic bread recipe from now on.

text:
Awesome, awesome!  My husband's first response was "the taste like sugar."  They were too sweet for him, but I loved them.  With the leftover rolls, I covered with a sugar glaze to make a sweet roll - this was really good.  I also tried it with half wheat and half white flour and I was very pleased with the results - still slightly sweet and very soft.  I have also used this recipe to make donouts and they turned out very tasty!!  Just roll the dough out into the shape you desire for you donout after the first rise then let rise a second time, fry in hot oil for about 4 minutes and cover with a sugar glaze.

text:
This recipe was got rave reviews from my family (especially my 10 year old son).  I made this recipe last night and tonight.  Last night I followed the recipe as directed and they were very flat (very flavorful - but no rise).  I made them again tonight and tonight I used bread flour instead of all-purpose and added about 1/4 cup as suggested below and also I used about 1/2 Tbsp butter on each round instead of 2 Tbsp and they rose perfectly and still had a great buttery flavor.  Thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
This is my first time using the bread machine for preparing dough.  It is so convenient, especially since I have a cool kitchen.  This is a wonderful recipe even though I modified it some.  I used 2-1/2 cups white bread flour, 1 cup whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup potato flakes.  I also added 1 tsp. Italian Seasoning and I made 15 rolls in a 9x13 pan.  I baked it for 15 minutes at 350 and then brushed the rolls with melted butter and baked for another five minutes.  Wonderful recipe.  Thank you so much for sharing!

text:
I was planning to make these for Thanksgiving and decided to try them tonight to make sure they were company quality -- in my opinion they were not -- but I am a pretty picky baker. I made these exactly as written and had no problems.  The dough was wonderful to work with, and the recipe was simple, but these were not as wonderful as I'd expected.  I guess I had high hopes for these because of the rave reviews and although they taste great with some butter and jam I will probably not use this recipe again (although I bet it'd make wonderful cinnamon rolls).   My husband gave me this "sorry you took so long to make these, they really aren't that great..." look and my mother had about the same opinion.  She did comment that they tasted like Bob Evans Restaurants' dinner rolls -- which I'd have to agree with, so if those are your favorite you'll love this recipe.

text:
I've been using the same dinner roll recipe for the past three years and I've always thought it was great, but I found out the hard way last Easter that they don't transport well and they taste mediocre the next day.  So, I thought I would try this one for a dinner at my sisters.  Well, this is my new dinner roll recipe!  I made 32 rolls instead of 16, and hubby and I ate 10 of them right out of the oven last night.  They were light, fluffy, and the crust was so soft, not tough or hard.  The sweetness was just right, not bland at all like others here have said.  Even better, the rolls were just as good the night after, warmed up in the oven.  I kept them covered in the fridge overnight and they were raved about at dinner.  My daughter begged me to make these from now on!  My oven tends to be on the hotter side, so I baked them at 350F for about 15 minutes.  They were perfect!  Thanks!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3120824.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made in the kitchenaid ike the first reviewer suggested, I warmed the milk and water together in the microwave.  I stirred the warm liquid into the mixing bowl with the sugar.  Sprinkled the yeast on top and allowed to foam for 10 minutes.  Added the butter, eggs and salt. After all the flour was mixed in I replaced paddle attachment with dough hook and kneaded for 8 minutes (scraping down after 5 minutes) . Let the dough rise in the covered bowl for 45 minutes. Scoop sticky dough out onto floured counter. Divided the dough into 16 pieces and placed 8 rounds into two pie pans.  Rise for another hour loosely covered with saran wrap. Baked @ 325F for 15 mins- my oven runs hot.  Will make these again and again. Too easy.

text:
These rolls are my family's favorite accompaniment to any nice meal.  I follow the recipe exactly when it comes to ingredients. As a tradition, my children roll out small balls of dough to create Cloverleaf Rolls.  Place three dough balls into each greased muffin cup, and cover for an hour, allowing rolls to double in size.  Then, brush with butter, and bake at 375 for 10-12 minutes.

Super easy to make! I followed the directions exactly and made these crescent rolls for Thanksgiving.  They rose during the 2 hour car ride, plus more at the house. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1939549.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was a little wary of the consistency of the dough, as it was very "cookie dough" like and unlike the typical bread or pizza dough I had ever worked with before.  The first rise didn't elevate as much as I expected it to within an hour, but I still proceeded to simply punch it down to about a 12" square and cut 12 equal square pieces using a pizza cutter.  I spaced them equally apart in a buttered cast iron skillet, and allowed them to rise again for approximately 3 hours before baking in a 350F oven.  THEY WERE AMAZING and everyone loved them!  I will definitely try this recipe again, as the dough is extremely easy to work with and I can completely understand the ease in forming crescent shapes or even cinnamon rolls.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used instant yeast and followed the directions for no bread maker. They came out thicker and heavier than I liked.  I allowed extra rising time to ensure a light and tender dough.  It's possible that I may have overworked the  dough and added to much flour when kneading. I will try these again using  regular yeast. I will also add a little more salt, they were sweet but sort of bland otherwise. The recipe is worth trying again.  
Update:  I tried this recipe again, I wanted to make cinnamon rolls.  I switched  my flour to bread flour, I used old fashioned flechmen  yeast, and I let the dough rest for ten minutes after I removed from mixing bowl, knead for only 5 minutes without adding additional flour. Since I was making cinnamon rolls, I added 1 teaspoon on vanilla extract before I added the flour. I let dough rise in warm oven for second rising.  I made a cream cheese frosting using only enough conf sugar to fluff. I didn't want tooth hurting rolls,  I also added nuts to the filling (brown sugar, cinnamon, butter) They were phenomenal!  So much better second time around!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-11-17T14:55:00.15
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
9672273
Display Name:
Andrea Hornok Madison
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5767341.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are phenomenal rolls. Incredibly simple even with out a bread machine.  They are my go-to recipe for everything now.  I obviously am joining the chorus of approval.  I don't have a bread maker so I modified the method to my Kitchen aid mixer.  I'm not sure if others have given instruction on how they did that, but I did the following:
I mixed the milk and water, heated up and added the yeast to bloom for 10 minutes.  Meanwhile I placed all the wet ingredients (minus the 1/4 cup butter) plus sugar into a the mixer and mixed. In a separate bowl mixed all the dry ingredients together.  After 10 minutes of the yeast mixture in the milk and water, I then I added it to the mixing bowl and mixed well.  Once mixed, I switched from the paddle to the dough hook, added the dry ingredients and mixed on medium speed for 2-3 minutes until dough was elastic.  Removed the hook, covered the bowl with plastic wrap and allowed the dough to rise for 30-60 minutes or until dough was at least double.  After that, I punched down the dough, briefly knead the dough and roll it out, cutting it into equal portions to form into balls (about the size of a golf ball or smaller) and placed into a buttered pan (1/4 C butter). Cover pan with a towel and allow it to rise for one hour, then bake.  They are phenomenal EVERY TIME.  I think for the Holiday season, I may turn this dough into cinnamon rolls-I'm positive those will be excellent too.

text:
These are very good, however I think rolling the dough out takes a lot of unnecessary time. Instead I sprayed a muffin tin with cooking spray and dropped three dough balls in each to make clover rolls. I do put a little butter between the ball before cooking. My kids like these because they can pull them apart. It saves a bunch of time and the rolls are just as good. A fun thing to do if you have kids make one roll with 4 balls and see who gets the lucky 4 leaf clover. Even my teens get excited if they are the ones to find it.

text:
I have never tried another roll recipe since I found these years ago! They're not only delicious but forgiving of mistakes and adjustments. I've made them in a bread maker and by hand, and the former was better, but they were great both ways! Unless it's Thanksgiving, I cut the butter and sugar each to 1/8 C - 1/4 C to save calories. I use mostly honey for the sugar, filling the measuring cup about 3/4 full with honey before filling the rest with white sugar. They get more rise when I proof the yeast for about 10 minutes with a bit of sugar and the water BEFORE it goes into my bread maker and also if I add vital wheat gluten. They're delicious when using white whole wheat flour, too!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am writing as I'm making this....
I heated the milk, water and sugar...I put in the Mixer, let it cool a little. Then added the salt mixed and then yeast! let proof 10 minutes...Then added the egg and butter, mixed with whisk attachment. Then I changed to hook attachment and added the flour 1.5 cups at a time, then 3/4 cups. Mixed. Took out and knead for a while. Then put in oiled bowl and let rise. I did this late, so I went to bed and the next morning....Nice and poofy! doubled in size...
Punched down, rolled in little rolls and put one ball in each small tin cupcake pan. Then I used the other half to make cinnamon rolls, which by the way, I've been wanting to do forever!!!! Let everything rise again (double in size). Baked the rolls for 15 minutes at 350 degrees. On half I sprinkled herbs and the other half, nothing, just sprayed PAM on both. These are tender little balls of goodness, very simple. Surprisingly, I prefer the ones without the seasoning. Maybe it's because they're a tad sweet. The cinnamon rolls I baked for 15-20 minutes at 350 degrees also. I'm very pleased with both! I will definitely make these again!!!! Yummy!

text:
Came out perfect.did it without bread machine. Proofed yeast with sugar, milk&water (110f).mixed dry ingredients then added flour half cup at a time into the yeast mixture along with butter(all the butter). Kneaded 10min on stand mixer.then let dough proof in greased bowl until double in volume.then rolled & shaped into 13balls &3 rolls (without buttering).let rise again until double in volume. Baked for 10-15 min, 400f.they turned out perfect.the strange part was I didn't butter the crescents when rolled out (ihad mixed it all in the dough), but they were still very fluffy & soft. I wish I had made all the croissants instead of buns (did them because they were suggested by others).im going to make them again this time all croissants like in the actual recipie.Lets see how they turn out.thanks Donna

text:
These were so good! The first ever rolls I have made, I didn't use a breadmaker but just followed the instructions of one of the other reviews (summer_lover - thanks!)and they turned out beautifully.  The only thing I would do differently next time is less sugar, they were quite sweet to have with an Irish stew but not so much that it detracted from the meal which was totally delicious all round. I recommend watching the video as I found it quite helpful, as a beginner.

None
text:
Absolutely delicious!!  Took to family dinner and there were two other large pans of rolls that another relative brought; I brought one pan of these rolls as I was just testing them out....told them they were all my guinea pigs =)  Well lets just say the other relative still had over a full pan left and I had 4 little rolls left haha.  Guess they liked them.  I made this recipe again except this time after the kneading process in the bread machine, I took the dough out and coated in oil and covered until it was doubled.  I punched the dough down and divided it in half.  Put each half in an 8 x 4 greased and floured pan.  Covered and let it rise until double in size again.  Baked in 350 degree oven for about 20-22 minutes.  Rubbed a stick of butter over top and sides of loaves for a glossy tender crust.  YUM!!!!  Came out perfect!!  One loaf is almost gone already in a matter of a few hours.  Will be making over and over.

Very good, but I expected them to be a little more buttery and the dough was a little wet, maybe I didn't measure the flour right. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This made an exceptional dough.  I have also enjoyed it as a cinnamon roll dough base - I put some (1 tsp?) cardamom in the dough and rolled it out in a long rectangle, then put the softened butter and cinnamon-sugar on it before rolling it jelly-roll style and cutting into 1" cinnamon rolls.  Heavenly?  Either way, make sure you give this dough ample to rise - it is a heavy dough and takes more time.  You can make these crescent rolls or cinnamon rolls ahead by putting the rolls very closely on a cookie sheet or 9x13 pan, and then freezing them overnight.  At this point you can take them off the pans and put them into ziplocs in the freezer.  When you are ready to use them, put them back on cookie sheets in the evening, cover with lint-free baking towels, and they will be ready to bake the morning!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely LOVE this recipe. It's really simple.....I usually have all the ingredients on hand. But it must be something about the ratio of fat to grains that makes these rolls the most consistently reliable and delicious every single time! Like others, I toss all the ingredients, exactly as written, into my breadmaker and set it to "dough", take it out 1.5 hrs later, roll it into 24 rolls (don't  be afraid to really work them in your hands....it makes them very tender) on a single 1/2 sheet baking pan  and let rise for 1.5 hrs. I like to use my oven to rise the rolls by setting it on its lowest setting (170°) and turn it off when it reaches temperature.  Then I put my rolls in to rise. When they've nearly tripled in size and are touching each other, I pull them out, turn the heat up to 400° as instructed, and bake for 10 mins. Absolutely perfect, every time. I will NOT buy rolls ever again! Cinnabon has lost my $$ too....this is perfect for cinnamon rolls as well. Experiment.....add garlic, rosemary, brush the top with egg, milk or butter.  The sky is the limit with these little clouds of goodness. But do stick to the basic recipe, word for word, before tweaking however you like. It is the PERFECT base recipe! I !an never thank you enough

text:
I have used this recipe so many times and every time it comes out perfect!  I've even added 1 tsp garlic and 2 tsp onion powder to use it for Italian night!  The best tip?  My mom always saved her potato water to use in her from-scratch bread she made every Saturday when we were kids, and if you cook your potatoes a "little" longer, then your potato water is a "little" thicker too, so use a little MORE, but boy does that make it great!  I have used this for bread, rolls, cinammon rolls, bierocks, and it is always perfect!!!! Try again if you didn't like it the first time, cause I bet you accidentally did something wrong!!! THANKS FOR SHARING THIS RECIPE!!!!

I also rolled them as thin as possible, then rolled several times, and I believe that made them lighter. I will make these my go to rolls from now on, they were so good!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to make these by hand instead of in a bread machine, but they still turned out wonderfully. I also didn't make them into crescents. I just rolled them into balls. The taste and texture weren't quite what I was expecting, but, WOW! They taste amazing! This is definitely my new go-to dinner roll recipe. Simple ingredients also are a plus. I did pour/brush melted butter over the top of the rolls once they were finished baking and out of the oven. It made the tops soft and added to the richness of the rolls. I highly recommend adding butter to the tops, unless you like chewier tops. My one and only gripe is that the rolls weren't completely done on the bottoms after 18 minutes at the given temperature. The tops were starting to turn a dark gold, so I took them out. Maybe at a lower temperature and a slightly longer bake time, they would bake completely on the bottom. However, the rolls are so delicious that you don't even notice the slight doughiness at the bottom. I also cut the sugar down to around 1/4 of a cup. If I were making cinnamon rolls (Which I might just try with this recipe), I would use the full 1/3 cup. Otherwise, excellent recipe!

text:
This bread is a staple in my home. I wanted a non cow dairy version of the bread so I substituted the milk for goats milk and the butter for a little bit less then 1/3 cup olive oil. I also went with 1/6 cup white sugar, 1/6 cup brown sugar and nixed the butter basting at the end. What resulted was a rich flavored roll that had great bounce and texture and taste. Sooooo yummy!

userID:
8076190
Display Name:
dlastqueen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
5

11

0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have a breadmaker either, but that didn't stop me from trying.  I read some of the other reviews and decided to "nuke the milk and water in the microwave" then add the yeast.  I didn't know if I should stir the yeast in or let it sit.  I stirred in the milk/water mixture and let it sit for 15 min. I mixed all the other ingredients except the last 1/4 cup of butter. I added everything together and let it rise for 1 hr.  I knead and punch the dough, separated into balls and let it rise for another hr (which worked!!) Popped them in the oven for 12 minutes, broiled for 3 minutes(which I shouldn't have done because the tops were tooooo brown) but the bottoms were not burnt (thank God!). These looked more like biscuits than rolls...when I try them again I will pay more attention to the oven temperature and time.

text:
Perfect rolls to go along with Christmas dinner! I started these in the bread machine and then rolled the dough into 20-25 balls and then let them rise in a 9X13 pan for an hour then baked for about 12 minutes, then froze them.  When it came time for Christmas dinner, I baked them (covered in foil) at 350 for 15 minutes or so (I think the oven in our cabin didn't heat very well so it took longer).  Everyone loved them and there were none left :)
