text:
Made it in my KA mixer and then let it rise for an hour.  Problem: it didn't double, at best it quartered (and I was bragging an hour earlier about how foamy my yeast was).  Had to have it ready for Christmas dinner so I just went with it.  Rolled it into crescents (I assumed it'd take a while because so many reviewers seem to make balls but it was really easy and fast with a pizza cutter).  The second rise went way better and they puffed even more in the oven.  I'm talking HUGE- big enough to use as an actual hot dog roll.  Next time I will make them a bit smaller.  Only took 9 mins in the oven.

text:
Did not have breadmaker, so mixed yeast and warm water and added to milk/butter/sugar mixture after cooling.  After letting dough rise in covered bowl for 1 hour, formed into 16 ball-shaped rolls and placed into rectangular glass pan, then let rise again (covered) for another hour.  The consistency was perfect, but the rolls were just a little too sweet for us.  Would probably cut down on the sugar next time, or maybe add a little more salt.  Overall, these were pretty easy to make.

So good.  I made two batches today.  One for Thanksgiving dinner (noon meal) and then I made another batch as cinnamon rolls for in the morning.  I increased the sugar for the 2nd batch, mixed up some butter, brown sugar and cinnamon and rolled them up, and sliced them with some dental floss. It was a brand new jar of yeast, so I am not sure what happened, but they still baked up pretty well.  In spite of this, the flavor and ease of preparation were amazing.

text:
Everything the reviews before mine are true!!!! I do catering and decided to change my dinner roll recipe and used this one. I was feeding 200. The rave reviews that I recieved. I also have been looking for a cinnamon roll recipe and used this and the only thing I did different was to add a 1/3 cup more sugar. Rolled the dough out and covered with butter and cinnamon/sugar. WOW!!!!! I also had some cream cheese frosting left in the refrige and used it also. I rolled the dough out like I would with cinnamon rolls and caked on the icing and then rolled them. Another WOW!!! Iced them in cream cheese frosting.        THANK YOU Donna for submitting this recipe. This is a real keeper.

text:
I made these rolls diary free(since we have a few lactose intolerant members in our family)using rice milk and margarine,instead of the milk and butter. I Mixed the dough  in my bread machine, separated it into 24  balls,  brushed with margarine , put in greased cookie sheets and then baked the rolls in the oven. They came out perfect ! In fact, my family agrees that those rolls are better than the rolls sold at the bakery. It became an all time favorite with our family.

text:
These were great, but you probably already knew that based on all of the great reviews! They reminded me of the rolls you get at Texas Roadhouse. After the first raise, I just pulled the dough into a long rope then cut into 8 pieces. Then I placed them on the cookie sheet and let them rise as is. I also brushed them with melted butter right out of the oven and it gave them a nice color and flavor. I split the recipe in half and made cinnamon rolls with the other half since there's only three of us.  It was a heavy carb night, but they were worth it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't have a bread machine, so I used my food processor to make the dough. I used reviews from the recipe and work at the "old fashion way". I followed instruction for my food processor regarding mixing the ingredients (flour goes together with butter and salt and later on slowly adding the "wet" ingredients) .  It turned out perfect! WE LOVED these!  Definitely will make again...

An update (11/17/2010)
I froze some of these by wrapping individually each roll in foil. Before dinner I just took these out, let them stand for sometime and put in the oven (still wrapped in foil) (350F) for some time (until soft). Worked like a charm. I also do the same trick with any frozen bread, always gives a great, soft, fresh bread.

text:
I was able to make these dairy free, and they still tasted great, and that is a 5 star in my book! I used vanilla almond milk and non-dairy, soy free 'butter', and half wheat flour. They came out a little dense, but that was probably my fault as I was making these while juggling a 4 month old and a sick 5 year old. I will do these again, but proof the yeast first in the bread machine and see if I can get them fluffy. Even if I can't, I will keep making them because the flavor was great. and with a little 'butter' melted on them... yum!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made up a batch of these, exactly per recipe ingredients, but with one fowel up: I added the softened butter after the flour and yeast.  After 3 minutes, my dough had formed into a beautiful, smooth elastic ball.  After forming these into 15 2 inch wide balls, I set them close together in a greased glass casserole (one size smaller than the standard 9 x 13 in), covered and let them rise for no less than 1 hour.  You MUST wait 1 hour for these to develop their fluffy texture.  After baking, they looked just like unglazed Hawaiian Sweet Rolls.  Delicious!  Slightly sweet from the sugar.  A little puff of heaven.

Display Name:
Katrina

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/75306.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is amazing. I used bread flour because I had more of that than AP on hand - the dough came out of the bread machine so fluffy and light, I divided it in half and made half as directed, spread about a tablespoon of butter over the rollec out dough and using a pizza cutter, cut into 8 wedges and rolled up - these came out so fluffy and delicious my guests couldn't believe I made them!  Then the other half I rolled into small balls and put three in a muffin tin each to make clover rolls.  We ate so many for dinner last night I had to make a fresh batch this morning for Easter brunch - not a problem though because they are sooo easy.  And I can imagine when I have more time playing with the dough to do all kinds of fun recipes for appetizers, dessert etc.  Oh and as a side note, I almost ran out of yeast for the second batch so I only had about 2tsp, maybe less, but they are still rising okay - maybe not quite as much or as fast as with the full amount of yeast so I recommend at least 2 and quarter tsp.

text:
It may have been my technique, but these rolls were very denseand I would prefer a light and airy roll.  Although, they do taste very good and I gave this recipe 4 stars.  I tried this recipe again and let my rolls rise longer in a warmer area (low temp oven) and they turned out much better.  The rolls were a little lighter and better, but I am looking for a recipe that makes "air-light" yeast rolls like those you find in restaurants that you put honey butter on and they melt in your mouth.  Although, this is a good basic dinner roll.

text:
These were some the most light, fluffy and tasty rolls I've had in a very long time.  I used to make dinner rolls all the time BY HAND and they came out fabulous, then I stopped for a number of years and tried using the same recipe and they came out hard as rocks!  So along with the rolls I threw the recipe out with them.  I think there was something I did back then that I didn't write on the recipe that clearly I'd forgotten.  This recipe turned out wonderfully!!  Thanks so much Donna. **For first time bread bakers, use the freshest ingredients as possible, especially the yeast, that too can make your bread hard.

text:
Here's what I did...I added 1 tsp. of granulated garlic to the dough mixture.  After that, I followed other reviewers idea of dividing the dough into 36 pieces and putting three pieces into each section of a muffin tin.  I then allowed the dough to rise a final time in the tin.  After rising, I brushed the rolls with butter and sprinkled each one with granulated garlic, parmesan cheese, salt, pepper, and dried parsley.  After baking, I again brushed the rolls with melted butter.  I took these to a potluck and people raved over them and were amazed that I made them myself.  Amazing!

text:
Yum!  I didn't shape them into the rolls the recipe recommended, I shaped them into regular rounds.  Everyone loved them!  I will make these again!  (Also used some of the extra dough to make cinnamon roll~ excellent!)  I also found that the dough does well when refrigerated.  I shaped the dough and put them into the baking dish before sticking them into the refrigerator.  The next day, I removed them and after coming to room temperature I let them rise.  Perfect.

text:
This a 5 stars one with no doubt! It is a fail-safe recipe even for beginners .... I have tried several time without any modification and they have come out exactly the same each time! One thing which bugs me is that the bottoms of the rolls get brown (look like burned)! Still it tastes pretty good. I wonder if anyone have suggestion to avoid this? I tried putting another pan underneath the one with rolls in it and bottoms are less burned .... Meanwhile, you may keep this in the fridge for several days in a plastic container (covered) and whenever you want to have them just microwave it for a few seconds and it would look like just come out of oven! :)

text:
These are perfect if you like a little "heft" to your rolls - not too heavy, mind you, but not feather-light, either. Perfect amount of sweetness, and great for sandwich rolls, too. I get rave reviews every time I make these, and they're really easy. I don't have a breadmaker, so I make these with my mini Bosch - all I do is let the yeast, sugar, and warm milk froth, add the egg and butter, whip, and then switch to the dough hook. I just add flour a half-cup at a time, and they turn out beautifully. Good luck!

I absolutely LOVE these rolls. I must be honest, last night was my third attempt. I didn't know much about baking yeast rolls so I know my other two failed attempts were due to "user error". I received a bread machine on Mother's Day from DH and tried the recipe last night and what a success!! I followed suggestions from other users: I used 1 cup of warm milk (did not use water at all), used SIFTED bread flour, and rapid rise yeast. I made them into rolls last night. My husband went crazy!!! To save our waistlines, I packaged some up and shared them at work today-they were all gone within 10 minutes. No one could believe I didn't buy them from a steak house!! I will try these some other time using my Kitchen Aid but for now, the bread machine yielded PERFECT results for me!!

text:
OMG!!! These are the best rolls ever.I don't have a bread machine so I put the milk, water, sugar,butter and salt in a pan and warmed up just until the butter melted.I added the liquid to the yeast and waited 5 minutes then I added the flour slowly, what I could not add I kneaded in the dough.I let it rise for one hour in the oven with a pot of hot water underneith. I made 13 rolls and baked as directed.Amazing!!!!!:)

text:
Holy cow! I was skeptical of the rave reviews but not anymore. First, the dough was airy. Hands down the best dough I've ever made. Second, I did not make these into crescents, rather divided into 17 balls and made them into Parker House rolls (flatten dough into a round, put a small amount of butter on one half of round, crease down the center of round with the back of a butter knife, and fold over). I baked these for 15 minutes at 350 degrees and the rolls were done all the way through. When the rolls came out of the oven they were virtually weightless. So light and airy and the taste was wonderful. This will be my new standard roll recipe.

text:
Oh what a disaster I had with these.  I decided to do the dough in my bread machine and followed the recipe exact.  When the dough cycle was over, the dough was so wet that I could pour it out of the pan, and the yeast was still setting on top.  So, I poured it into a bowl and added flour to get it to a thicker consistency and also to blend in the yeast.  Believe it or not, they actually turned out pretty good and my husband actually had 5 of them for lunch.  I will stick with my old faithful recipe though and continue to mix my rolls by hand.

text:
So, so good! Very light and soft.  I didn't make crescents - I made 16 round rolls - they were HUGE - next time I'll make them smaller because they do rise a lot, but that's what makes them so light and fluffy!  Oh, and they are forgiving - I only used 2.25 tsp yeast (instead of 2.5) and they were still perfect.  I also forgot the egg and realized it after it had been in the bread machine a few min so I took the dough out, kneeded in an egg and put it back in.  Baked at 375 for 15 min after brushing with an egg/milk mix.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The best rolls ever!  My husband could not stop eating them.  I made them in the bread machine, and then I always let my breads rise in a warm oven.  I let it preheat for 2-3 minutes with a bowl of warm water (glass or ceramic bowl) on the bottom rack.  Then I turn it off and put the bread on the top rack.  This way you always have a warm, draft-free place to let them rise.  I divided the dough and made them in pie plates as suggested by other reviewers.  I baked them for 10 min, and the tops got just a little too brown.  The insides were still great, but next time, I'll only bake them 8-9 minutes.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is a keeper! I really liked the taste of the finished product. I followed the suggestions of another review by Suzy and mixed in my stand mixer starting with the softened butter, salt, sugar and egg. I then added the yeast, water, and milk mixture until combined. I then added the flour slowly as suggested. I also used quick rise yeast, but for some reason I have trouble getting a nice rise on all bread. I think it is because my house is just not warm and humid enough so I turned the oven on and heated to 200 degrees and shut it off. I opened the door and let it cool off a little. The I placed in rolls in the oven to rise and that did the trick. My husband loved them and so did my son. I think I will try a dinner roll shape next as I this time I made a croissant shape this time. Oh, I have a bread machine, but it is quicker to use the mixer and really easy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Calling this a roll would be a vast understatement...the butter flavor's so pronounced, and the crescent shape gives it this awesome flaky, buttery layers...it's more of a crossaint. I learned a lot making tis recipe...for my oven, it absolutely mandatory that these be baked on the highest shelf...the ones on the bottoms had burnt bottoms but had overly light tops while the ones on the tops were perfectly golden on top, and light on the bottom, as they should be. As this was my first time making these, I only cut the butter by 1 TB...only used 2 TB in the dough, but since I'm a butter cutting freak...next time I'm using only 2 TB in the spread on the crescent...might be a little less buttery, but I think the great soft texture will still be there. And I want to try them as regular rolls( that way it cut out the 1/4 cup of butter altogether and would be less time consuming) I'm so proud of myself...I actually made great rolls that my whole family devoured! Oh, and I got 18 out of this recipe, and next time I'll make 20.

userID:
2408418
Display Name:
Ms. gayle
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10

33
favoritesCount:
264
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/40314.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the best.I don't use a bread machine, but cannot imagine they could be any better. I am very oldfashion when it comes to baking breads and pastries. I usually make homemade croisants for my Thanksgiving & Christmas. Running out of time this year I made this recipe for Thanksgiving. The dough was so easy to work with I have never felt anything like it. I do all of my kneeding by hand. The smell while cooking was amazing. I read many reviews, I reduced the sugar to 1/4c and a lot shared that they had difficulty with burned bottoms. I adjusted for this by baking at 375* and you have to ALWAYS use parchment paper under any type of rolls or buiscuts. You will have chef quality bottoms. I use the unbleached paper and it is not any more costly that regular wax paper. I did have to bake about 15 minutes, but started checking at 10. Don't overbake, even if the tops are not browned too much. I was concerned about the moistness which did disapate once the initial baking heat reduced to warm for serving. I used a 9x13 and got 15 descent sized rolls, uniformly sized and shaped. Absolutely spectacular!

text:
I just made these rolls today for our Thanksgiving lunch and I just loved them!
Fluffy and flavorfull, like I wanted.
I dont have a bread machine so I use the warm water from the recipe to bloom the yeast, I put the warm milk, sugar, and the bloomed yeast into a bowl I added the egg, salt and butte mixed everything and added the flour. Kneeded the dough for few minutes put it into a greased bowl to raise for about an hour then formed the rolls ( regular balls ) then inot a greased casserole and let them raise untill nice and puffy ( the oven was busy anyway ), brushed with milk and baked them until golden brown.
A success, thank you for this great recipe is in my favorites now.

text:
This is a keeper.  After reading others I also do not have a bread machine so I threw the dry ingredients together with  2.5tsp instant yeast.  Warmed the water, milk,butter then added the egg which was warmed in a cup before opening. Mixed the dry into wet cup at a time. Also needed to add about half cup extra flour while kneading. I made round rolls which did not last the night since all were gone.  Have made this twice already and intend to try as cinnamon rolls when I have the time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Even though I made a few changes to this recipe, I'm convinced it would've been great as written anyway. First of all, I halved the recipe being that I only needed dinner rolls for two people. I used white bread flour instead of all purpose flour, and I used sea salt as ususal. Also, I totally forgot about spreading the butter on top of my dough round until after I had already rolled up my crescents. So I just melted the butter and brushed it on the rolls - once before baking and once half way through. Great recipe, the rolls had a light crust and fluffy insides with good subtle flavor. If I was going to change anything I'd just add a pinch more yeast and maybe an extra tablespoon or two of sugar for more flavor, and I definitely want to remember rolling the butter into the crescents next time. I might experiment with using some whole wheat flour or some honey instead of sugar as well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made the rolls, I used a mixer and the texture of the rolls turned out part bread part biscuit... not sure if I did something wrong.  They were not as fluffy as I hoped they would be, but they were still good. I found the dough to be extremely sticky and had to add extra flour.  I also tried making cinnamon rolls with half of the dough, but they turned out more like cinnamon bread than rolls. 
The 2nd time I tried this recipe, the rolls turned out PERFECT.  They were sooo fluffy, soft and soooo YUMMY.  What I did differently...
1)I used my bread machine AND 2)bread flour to make the dough... I had to go somewhere so when the dough was finished, I put it in a buttered bowl (Pam spray) and covered it with a damp cloth. After a couple hours, the dough had risen so I punched it down and rolled and buttered my dough out as the recipe called.  I let the crecent dough rise for another hour before I baked them.  I also cut the amount of sugar to 1/4 C and it was perfect... not too sweet.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/51305.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these rolls for Easter dinner-- I doubled the recipe and finished them at about 3 AM the night before.  I put them in the fridge on their first rise (as I don't have a breadmaker, I used the Kitchenaid method) because I had to work.  As with many yeast bread recipes, I feel that the slow rise in colder temperatures brings out a more complex flavor.  That being said, I completed the recipe as follows with the addition of a simple eggwash before putting them in the oven.  I tried one as they were cooling on the racks and I was very disappointed in the flavor versus "time spent" ratio.  I felt that they weren't anything spectacular.

Then I tried another one as I was packing the food up to bring to the family's house for dinner and they were great!  They pulled apart wonderfully and the complex flavor was complimented by the butter.  I don't know about everyone else's experience with this recipe, but I think they taste better the day after.  Good roll standard recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
these were ok, but i altered them pretty significantly.  i replaced the butter with oil.  I made potato bread instead using 3c flour + 3/4 c cooked mashed potatoes so that the bread would stay moister.  This was a critical change!  they became a billion times better.  As a result, i reduced the total liquid (milk + water) from 1 c to 3/4 c.  they are also really good if you brush honey on the rolls after the second rise, but before you bake them.  As a basic dough, this recipe is pretty phenomenal.  i am going to try making onion bread or another salty variety next.  they are soft, pillowy, moist, and delicious, esp with the potatoes.  try this recipe!

text:
I didn't use a bread machine because I enjoy kneading dough myself. I dissolved the yeast and 1 tbsp of the sugar in the warm water and let it proof for about 15 minutes. I warmed the milk in the microwave then melted the butter in the milk. After mixing in the remain sugar, the salt, and the egg I added the milk mixture to the yeast mixture then stirred in enough bread flour to make the dough manageable for kneading. These rolls were very nice. Just the right touch of sweetness.

text:
These made the best rolls!!!

I made the receipe exactly as shown except I used my bread machine on the dough setting.  Then I made 12 balls and placeed them in a 9X13 pan, covered them and let rest for 1 hour.  I then basted them with melted butter and baked until golden brown.  They turned out big, soft, fluffy and great.  Also great for the next couple days as we used then for ham sandwiches.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made these for Thanksgiving. They were very easy compared to others I have done, and turned out great! I was worried they would be too sweet, which I am not fond of in a dinner roll, but they were perfect. 

I kneaded the dough in a bowl( no breadmaker). This is somewhat sticky dough, so I found I needed to work in at least an additional 3/4 cup flour to make it workable and rubbery for rolling out, but that was fine. 

Also, if you roll it out on a floured surface, and the rolls come out a bit "dusty" on the bottoms after cooking, baste with melted butter after they are out of the oven. They look perfect, and browned very well.

Caught my boyfriend snacking on one this morning, without asking....(smile)

text:
These are super easy with an excellent sweet bread taste.  But they are not too sweet to make into other types of rolls.  I made these twice now as sandwich buns.  After removing from my bread machine, I use my food scale and weigh 2 oz. of dough each.  This makes about 18 buns.  Shape into buns, let rise and bake as directed.  I didn't even use the additional butter and they were delicious!

text:
Fantastic recipe!  Served them last night with lemon chicken and our guests raved about them.  This was despite the fact that I had forgotten to put the paddle inside the bread machine and  had to dump everything out, mix the dough by hand and let the machine finish the kneading and rising.  I made them just like the recipe advised and used a pizza cutter to divide the dough into wedges. They rose beautifully and the "pillowy" texture is a great description for them. We can not buy "Pillsbury Doughboy" type dinner rolls where we live overseas so these will be made A LOT!!!! Thanks so much for the AllRecipes site.

text:
Really good recipe!  Clarification for all those whose reviews said they didn't understand the shaping process.  To make the crescent shape, just think of rolling out and cutting pizza dough.  Then roll up from the wide, or crust end, and bring together the points together.

text:
I am so tickled with this recipe.  I tried these rolls and they are fantastic.  They are so buttery tasting you don't need to put anything on them.  I am now making them for Easter dinner.  I definitely put these in my recipe box.  They are also so easy!! I did not use the bread machine but mixed as they said and let the mixture of water,milk,sugar heat to 115 degrees.  I added the yeast and timed 5 minutes.  I put flour,salt and egg in bowl.  After 5 minutes I mixed together.  I let rise 1 hour each time.  Perfect!!Thank you.

text:
These are outstanding! Like many others, I don't have a bread maker, so had to do it by hand. I don't make these into croissants, but standard dinner roll shape. After proving the yeast in the water, milk, and tablespoon of sugar, I mixed the rest of it together. I then kneaded it for about 10ish min, then let it rise. I usually punch it down two times before shaping them into rolls. One time I made them with my sourdough starter instead of the instant yeast, and I didn't like them too much as just a roll (plain nor buttered), however they were delicious for sandwiches!

text:
Fabulous recipe ! Followed as is, but turned it into 12 huge  cinnamon rolls, with the traditional sticky bun bottom , with pecans.....so yummy. After rolling and cutting  into 12 wheels and placing in pan that had sugar ,pecan mixture, I let them rise in a warm oven for 45 minutes. Then I pulled them out of the oven and preheated oven to 350 degrees, and baked then for 25-30 minutes. Pull and immediately flip them onto parchment or foil, gooey side up. They were huge and so yummy......thanks Donna. Beautiful dough to work with.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/646388.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to recipe for dinner rolls. It is very similar to the recipe my grandmother used. When I know I won't have time,  sometimes I make the dough, form the rolls, put them in the baking pan, cover them with plastic wrap and put them in the refrigerator overnight.  Wake up in the morning and pop them in the oven at 400F or 200C.  The texture of these rolls when they are refrigerated overnight is WONDERFUL. I have also substituted 1 cup of wheat flower for 1 cup of the bread flour for a nice change.  As a side note, for those whose bread came out crumbly, If you make it by hand: add three cups of flour  in the initial mix. Put just enough of the other 3/4 cups of flour so the dough can be kneaded. The less flour over 3 cups you put in, the better the texture will be.
Review:

5

text:
This recipe made awesome dinner rolls.  I live near Denver so altitude is a consideration.    I used my bread machine but made the following alterations - added a couple of tablespoons extra of milk, decreased the sugar by a tablespoon and used only  2 teaspoons of yeast.   Otherwise I followed the recipe.  I did find that they cooked really fast - probably 6 minutes.  That may also be contributed to the altitude here.   I found the dough was a bit soft to spread on the softened butter.  Next time I will melt the butter and brush onto the dough before cutting into wedges and then brush the tops of the rolls with melted butter before cooking.  Now I have to try to keep them safe from being eaten before my Easter dinner!

text:
These are great! I make them in Alberta so I add more flour than the recipe calls for to account for elevation, about 30g extra. I also reduce the sugar to 1/4cup as they're too sweet otherwise. I've made these rolls dozens of times and they always get rave reviews. I started making them in my mini cupcake tin and make 24 rolls per batch, and they bake to a decent size dinner roll. I also brush with meted butter as soon as they come out of the oven. These rolls are lovely and a staple on family holidays!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5613011.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  These are the best rolls I've ever made!  I was looking for the perfect roll recipe to adopt, and this is it!  The dough is lovely to work with, soft but not too soft, easy to work with.  And the rolls turn out very light and airy, just delicious.  As many of you wrote, I do not have a bread machine, so made these the old fashioned way, using the method posted by Summer_lover.  The first time I made them, I followed the recipe exactly.  The second time, I tried a couple of variations.  I increased the sugar to 1/2 cup.  Then, I used half the dough to make crescents, which I sprinkled with parmesan cheese after spreading with the butter.  With the other half, I made parkerhouse rolls.  After rolling out the dough, I used a 3" cookie cutter to cut out rounds of dough.  Then I dipped each in melted butter and folded in half before placing in a dish to rise the second time.  They both turned out to be big hits with my family!  I'm looking forward to trying other variations as well.  Thank you, Donna, for an incredible recipe!

userID:
5718412
Display Name:
x-nmac
isPro:

followersCount:

104
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were great! Like a previous reviewer, I mixed the water and milk, heated in the microwave for about a minute, poured into mixing bowl, stirred in the sugar and then the yeast. 2.5 teaspoons active dry yeast from the jar. Waited 10 minutes, then mixed in the salt, butter and egg, then slowly mixed the flour in using the dough hook attachment. I found that I did not need all of the flour, probably about 1 cup less than called for. Let dough rise 45 minutes in the bowl, covered. Punched down and cut into 90-100g balls, placed in muffin tins. Let rise little more (20-30 min?) Brushed with egg white mixture and baked. Excellent!  Thanks!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great roll recipe! I used a bread machine and it turned out great. If your bread machine instructions say to put the yeast directly into the machine with the other ingredients without prepping it first, do not do it! I prep all my yeast, including instant yeast! It improves the rising of the dough. Mix the warm water with the sugar, and dump the packet of yeast in. Let it sit until it’s getting a little foamy & has that yummy yeast smell. While you’re waiting, warm the milk and mix in the egg and softened butter. Dump that into the bread pan, followed by the flour and salt. Then stick the pan in the machine & you’re set!

userID:
3059233
Display Name:
slcgirl3
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
51
favoritesCount:
1347
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  Fantastic!  I didn't even let it rise the full time the second time, and the rolls turned out great!  Everyone at the table loved them.  The bread was light and fluffy inside, and had just enough texture on the outside.
The way I made these was based on another reviewer's comments - I combined the water and milk, then microwaved them.  Added in the sugar.  Checked the temperature to make sure it wasn't too hot, then added in the yeast from the packets I have.  Let it sit for about 15 minutes, then mixed in the salt, egg, and butter.  Added in the flour about a cup at a time, mixing well in-between.  Turned out the dough onto a moderately-floury surface and kneaded it for a couple minutes.  Put it in an oven-safe bowl that I had sprayed with cooking spray, then covered it was plastic wrap that also had cooking spray on it.  Put the bowl in a warm oven (I had preheated the oven to 160, then turned off the heat).  Left it in there for an hour.  Took it out, punch down the down, then split the dough into two.  Each portion was rolled out into a 12-inch circle.  Cut each circle into 8 wedges.  Brushed the top of each wedge with melted butter, then rolled each wedge into the specified shape.  I only let it sit for about 15-20 minutes.  Baked it at 375 for close to 15 minutes, pulling them out when golden.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
I used oster bread machine dough setting, add wet ingredients first, then dry ingredients. Made a well in the flour and added 1 1/2 tsp bread machine yeast.  After the dough setting was completed. Dough was split into 12 balls and placed in a lightly oiled baking pan. I put the baking pan in the refrigerator for baking the next day for dinner. The rolls came out light and fluffy. They were delicious!

country:

text:
FIVE STARS! These turned out amazing. I did not have a bread maker so I dissolved the sugar in the warm water/milk mixture, then added the yeast to this, stirred and let dissolve for like 10 minutes. Mixed the egg salt and butter into this, then mixed in the flour one cup at  time. 

I made crescents as directed, and man... these turned out so light and airy almost flaky. I was NOT expecting these to be so good.  I suspect the softened butter may have contributed to this texture, as i softened it in microwave, being careful to not let it melt.

I will keep making this again and again. Next time I may cut down on the sugar to try making garlic bread by using a butter and garlic spread on the rolled out dough before cutting into slices. Five star recipe!

text:
Food porn! Absolutely wonderful! I don't have a bread machine so I followed K PRAPER's guide and it worked out perfectly. My only objection to this recipe is that I have a hard time parting with so much butter, I didn't smear the last 1/4 cup on the dough, I just rolled it out and made the crescents dry. They came out fine and seemed plenty rich enough to me but maybe they'd tear apart for buttering easier if I'd smeared them up. I'll definitely be making these again (and again, and again) but the bean-counter in me says to try it next time substituting shortening for the butter and see what happens.

text:
This is my standard roll recipe, the only thing I have ever had to do was tweak the amount of flour, and add an additional 1/4 cup of sugar to warm water (used to proof the yeast , makes for a sweeter roll--similar to Texas Road House). I also turn the pan of baking rolls half way through (to ensure even baking) and  baste rolls with melted butter the last  3 or so minutes of baking,  Cooking and baking is an extension of love and my family LOVES me when I make these rolls!

This is wonderful dough!  I make the dinner rolls with it and they are a hit. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7461745.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These worked out very well! I was looking for a recipe I could use for both dinner rolls and cinnamon rolls. I saw this one first and tried it. I haven't had a bread machine for 20 years and my circa 1950's  KitchenAid mixer (it was my great-grandma's) was not up to that task. So I put all the ingredients into my Bosch mixer fitted with dough hooks and went with that. In hindsight, since I was using regular active dry yeast I really should have dissolved it in the liquids first—but I forgot.  So I held off on adding the salt and butter until the yeast was more dissolved throughout the dough to give it more of a fighting chance. The resulting ball of dough came out very nice. It was a humid day so I added only 2T additional flour to make the dough workable. Cutting the dough ball in half yielded 12 dinner rolls and 4 monster cinnamon rolls. Can't wait to try it again!

text:
A good roll is hard to find. These are the best rolls I've ever made. I t made a beautiful silky dough and when baked made a delicious pillowy roll with a great taste. Even two days later they were still good. I substituted "I Can't Believe it's Not Butter" for regular butter in the dough and will use it again. Also mixed the yeast with the warm water before adding to the pot.
I did the crescents, half four to a circle and the other eight. I think the eight is the way to go. Not much trouble to do the crescents and they do look nice.
These are going to be a regular here.

These are the BEST ROLLS EVER. I've been making them for several years, and my family members call ahead of family reunions and stuff to make sure I'm bringing the rolls. Recently, I've started subbing 3 cups of Bob's Red Mill stone ground whole wheat flour for the 3 3/4 cups of all purpose. They're still fluffy and delicious!

text:
These are amazing rolls.  I've made them several times now and did both the cinnamon rolls and regular.  For the cinnamon rolls, I just took the butter you spread on top before rolling and added sugar/cinnamon, then rolled it up like a jelly roll and cut. Baked for the same amount of time.  This recipe does make two 9" round cake pans full, so you can do both types of rolls easily.

text:
Best rolls and so easy to make!! I proofed the yeast in my kitchenaid mixer with the milk and sugar. Added the rest of the ingredients and kneaded in mixer for about 7 minutes. I followed the recipe and I never thought I would be able to make crescent rolls!! Just cut rolled out dough in half and then cut the halves into halves and get rolling!!  Baked at 350 for 15 minutes as my oven runs hot.Thank you for a wonderfully easy recipe

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These rolls are soft and chewy on the inside but have a good crust. I do not own a bread machine, so I mixed by hand and kneaded by hand as well. The 1/8 cup flour I added while kneading did not adversely affect the result at all. I also used bread flour instead of all-purpose. Finally, I brushed the butter on the top of the rolls before baking rather than spreading it onto the circles. My family thought they were rather sweet, which I guess I should have known from the name. Next time I make them, it will be with half the amount of sugar.

text:
A newbie to bread-making with yeast, this is the 3rd recipe I've tried, and the first recipe I've LOVED!  I was so excited that I did a dance when I took the first bite.  I even called my mother to come over and "see what I did!".  They are soft, chewy, delicious.  Not too sweet at all.  I made them all by hand, as I really want to learn the feel of kneaded dough.  Followed the directions of some others, and kneaded for about 9 minutes.  They were fantastic as buns, and the other half as Cinnamon Buns.  Will make again for sure!

text:
Really loved it. The dough seemed really dry when in the bread machine so I added almost 1/4C of water and then when I cut the dough to roll into balls the dough was still pretty dry so I had to make sure my towel was nice and wet the whole time they were rising by wetting with warm water occasionally. Maybe it was a really dry day here in CO but we just loved the rolls and I will def be using this recipe again just with a bit more water. Thanks :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful! I altered the recipe to make 24 and made 24 large rolls.  To do this I had to use 3 1/3 tsp. of yeast. Awkward, but it worked fine. I used the traditional method since I don't have a bread machine.   I measured the dough on my kitchen scale and made them each 2-2.3 ounces each. I followed the suggestion to microwave the milk and water for 1 min. 15 sec. I didn't use the butter on top of the dough. I left them in too long,so I'll make sure to check them early next time--I think the tops stay pretty light when the bottom is done. The in-laws LOVED them!

text:
I loved these rolls with the exception that I need to figure out how to avoid burning the bottom. The first time I made them following the recipe. I was using a dark pan and a gas oven so I thought maybe that was the problem. The second time I made them I added about 2 Tbsp. of honey (fantastic!) and baked them at a lower temperature (350), for less time (7-8 mins) on parchement in an electric oven. I thought for sure that would do the trick, but, they still burned. Next time (and I will make them again) I'll probably try 325 or 300 and watch them even more closely. They really are fantastic, even when I burn them!

text:
I make a lot of bread rolls as my family loves eating soups and stews! This recipe is by far my favourite! The results are light slightly sweet rolls, with a crispy golden crust! I made mine in my kitchen-aid mixer using the dough hook , as I do not have a bread machine- and they turned out perfectly! My family loved them and devoured them as soon as they hit the table! Instead of using melted butter to glaze the rolls, I used milk with about 3 tablespoons of sugar! This turns a lovely golden in the oven and also tastes beautiful- especially with sesame seed on pumpkin/pepitas seeds on top! This recipe is my favourite and I will continue to make it whenever we have soup--- so regularly! Thank you! It has been exactly the types of rolls that I have been looking for!

My first batch was a little too browned (10 min.) on the bottom so took out the second batch a minute earlier(9 min.) and they were perfect. text:
This is my favorite recipe for sweet rolls. Once I remove the dough from the machine,I form them into walnut-size balls,dip in melted butter,then let rise about 45 minutes. I bake them at 350 instead of 400 so the bottoms don't over-brown. I posted a close-up photo so you can see the light and fluffy texture.

text:
Wonderful - made with my KA mixer as per instructions of other reviews. Let dough rise for an hour, punched down, rolled into about 18 balls and placed in lightly Pam-sprayed 9X13 glass dish. Let rise again for about an hour, baked 350 for 14 minutes. My son is asking why I don't make these all the time, and I need to put them away right now or there will be none for the turkey dinner tomorrow.

text:
These rolls are DELICIOUS. I wouldn't even call them "sweet," necessarily. (I realize they contain 1/3 c of sugar!) They remind me of what my husband and I call "pillows of heaven" -- rolls from Golden Corral (which is the single reason we'd go there).

I've made these twice and although they seemed slightly different each time, they were both VERY good.

I've used 3/4 c whole wheat flour just to see, and they were great. All all-purpose was great, too.

I didn't make them into croissants, I just balled them up and made them into rolls to use for sandwiches or whatever, and it saved me a lot of time and mess, and they were still great.

This is a keeper for sure.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fluffy and nicely sweet rolls, very versatile dough.  Also SO much tastier (and cheaper) than store-bought bread and rolls!  I have used this recipe to make round dinner rolls (I shaped the dough into balls instead of rolling and cutting, and used the last amount of butter listed to brush on tops before baking) and as a base for cinnamon rolls.  They disappear VERY quickly! For those who prefer less sweet rolls, decrease the amount of sugar to 2 or 3 Tbsp. Then I like to make them into bread sticks and brush with garlic butter.  It also makes a good thick pizza crust dough if you only let it rise about 5-15 minutes.  One of my favorite recipes!

text:
I love the sweet, buttery flavor this recipe delivers.  You need to adjust the sugar and butter to your taste.  I make the dough in the bread machine.  First, I heat the milk, water and butter until the butter melts.  Then I add the egg.  Then I add the dry ingredients with the yeast last.  That way the liquid is cooled by the flour before the yeast comes in contact.  I halved the recipe to yield 12 rolls which I bake in a cake pan.

I've tried many dinner roll recipes in the past, but always went back to the frozen dough because the recipe I tried wasn't worth the effort.  But not this time!!  I used my bread machine and followed the recipe exactly.  I think they could have baked a few minutes longer than the 12 minutes I used, or maybe if I just left them on the baking sheet to cool slightly that would have been enough.  I have my family over for Thanksgiving dinner and will be making these rolls this year.   My family (especially my younger son) are "roll freaks", so I'll have to do a double recipe!  They are going to LOVE these rolls!!

These are so easy and absolutely amazing!  I made 16 dinner rolls and used quick rise yeast so there was no need to let the dough rise twice.  I took the dough out of the machine after it was done kneading, shaped into rolls and let rise for about 45 min. - 1 hr.  and they were ready for the oven.  Will make again and again!

text:
I've never worked with yeast before and don't own a bread maker but read the reviews and gave it a try for Christmas dinner. My first batch looked promising. I used a mixer and the dough was soft and didn't need extra flour. However, it didn't rise. I baked it anyways and it was like a rock. My second attempt, I followed Kevin's suggestion by mixing the warm water, milk, & yeast together then add the other ingredients. But my dough was pretty sticky but it did rise. I scooped them out with some spoons and put the dough in a 13x9 pan and let them rise again. After baking, I froze them for a couple of days. Thawed and heated them up for Christmas dinner. Everyone liked them. I thought sweet and fluffy, but a little dry, possibly because I froze them? Hoping the 3rd time I'll hit bingo.

text:
I made these using my KA mixer and although their not super easy to make, they are definetly fun to make and even better to eat :) This is my 4th time making bread and after my second try they came out perfect :) (I forgot to add the egg and added too much flour the first time and they came out like rocks... tasty rocks tho lol!) I ended up adding less flour than the recommended amount, maybe like 2.5-3 cups but it really just depends on the weather and what not when it comes to making bread, or so I've heard. The timing was also a little bit longer, maybe like 15-18 mins in my oven. I'm making them again as soon as I finish my finals at school!

text:
Wow! I love making bread but rolls always seem to be a little harder to do. Maybe because I want them to have a fluffier texture than bread, which I like a little on the dense side. These were super easy! I made them for the first time on Turkey day for a dinner I didnt know we were going to until that morning and they were raved about:) I made them without a breadmachine and did find they did a little better if I let the yeast proof in the milk and water. Also it took a little bit more flour than the recipe called for to get that nice smooth texture. I have made 6 batches in 2 weeks:D It is now my go to roll recipe:)

text:
I made these rolls in my kitchenaid mixer - using the paddle.  I don't have a bread maker so I made this directly in the mixing bowl.  I warmed up the water & milk in the microwave and added all dry & wet ingredients together - mixed for 2 min after mixed added the egg (scrambled) to the dough mixture.  Mixed for another minute. After that I put the bowl near the heat of the oven to let the dough raise.  I will be making these again this christmas - turned out really soft & light - good with a smear of butter when warm out of the oven!

text:
These are really tasty.  I messed them up somehow; either because I didn't know beforehand that I needed to allow 20 minutes for the yeast to proof (learn something new everyday, haha!) or because I'm at more than 7000 feet above sea level where I'm at, they were not light but rather dense.  They are still amazingly good.  I dipped them in some homemade chicken soup that was seasoned with cayenne, and I must say the contrast of the spicy and sweet was delicious!  Next time I will try allowing 20 minutes for the yeast before adding the other ingredients to see if they end up lighter.

text:
Oh, these are wonderful! I won't be paying the Dough Boy any more money. ;) I've made these two times now, and both times (due to unforeseen circumstances) the dough ended up sitting in my bread maker on the "keep warm" setting for over an hour. Oops! But they still turned out great -- I just formed them into crescents and only let them rise for ten or fifteen minutes before baking. My family loved them.  Can't wait to try them the proper way someday!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't have a bread maker, so I followed the advise of other bakers. I mixed the water and milk, nuked in in the microwave for 1 minute and added 2 teaspoons yeast and a bit of sugar. I let it activate about 20 minutes and poured it into the bowl of my KitchenAid, then stirred in the rest of the  sugar until it dissolved,  then mixed in the salt, butter and egg, then I started mixing the flour a half cup at a time. I let it rise for about 45 minutes in the bowl, then punched it down, divided it into rolls and let it rise for another hour, then baked for 10 minutes at 350 degrees. Yum!

text:
Very nice roll. I'm eating one right now! It is the 4th of July week end and I'm making 4 batches of these (72) for a party on Sunday. I love the texture and the flavor is wonderful. I made 2 batches of regular dough and made one each of red and blue! I know how awful does that sound!! LOL Hey, it's VERY patriotic!! I'm sure they'll all go down to the tummy just fine! If your curious, I used McCormick's food coloring. I added 40 drops of color to each batch. The recipe made right at 925-930 grams of dough and I made each roll 50g. I got 18 nice rolls out of each. Try them, you'll be glad you did!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my! First time making rolls and husband loved them.  So good that he wants to take some to work for his co-workers.  I do not own a "bread machine" so I followed the Review on Feb. 7, 2004 by K about using a "mixer"...and only change I made was to use "honeybutter" in place of  "butter".  I found how to make "honeybutter" on this site.  And used "rock salt".  Also, after the two tries...I see the rising part is very important so I did 1 hour for 1ST rise (I set the oven on lowest temp..170 and soon as a saw the flames, I cut the oven off and put the rolls in the oven..can not open oven door until ready to come out for 2ND rise)  and 1 hour for 2ND rise (this time on top of 200 degrees oven)....All this came out so delicious...thanks Donna...

These rolls were fantastic! This was my first time ever making bread - to the point where I googled what it meant to knead and punch the dough! I was a little confused about timing so I accidently let the dough rise for 45 min. before I kneaded it, and just altogether I think I let them rise too long.  But they still came out terrific! 13 min. in a 350 oven was perfect!

text:
Everyone loved these!  I rolled them up like the recipe says, they made good little crescent-like rolls that are probably much healthier than the flaky ones! I should have put the point slightly under the roll for baking, but will next time.  The points sort of unrolled and got a little crispy.  Great flavor, great texture, even though I froze and thawed them before baking.  Baked only 10 minutes and were perfectly golden and soft.  I did not use a bread machine.  Very tasty, will be making a few loaves today :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used K Praper's instructions on how to make w/no bread machine. I rarely make bread so I was hesitant when I saw the dough, kneaded the dough and then rolled into ropes to make knots. My bet was I'd have some attractive-looking rocks of cooked dough because the dough seemed tough and heavy and didn't knead into a really smooth dough--I overdid the flour and could have used 1/2 a cup or so less. And I thought the risings, particularlly the first, didn't rise much at all. I also did a terrible job of making even-sized rolls--some ended up twice the size of others. I was so worried I made another recipe (one of the quick recipes) as a back up. Totally unnecessary--these were wonderful. Best when out of the oven of course but fine heated up. Husband just ate one cold out of the leftovers and mentioned how good they were. Used a silpat and kept oven heat lower to 375 (oven bakes hot), done in 20.

This was my first time making bread of any kind and these turned out pretty well.  Make sure you put the dough somewhere warm to rise.  I started putting them on the counter and they didn't rise much.  Then I put them on the top of the stove when I had the oven going and they began to rise much more quickly.

I am terrible at making rolls or bread for that matter. This is my second recipe attempt at making dinner rolls and so far (though I've only tried one other) these were the best! I thought I'd fail miserably, but I only failed half miserably. The only problem I have is proofing my yeast; I have a feeling my yeast is a bit old. text:
I made these for the first time today.  I thought the recipe (and dough it makes) so SO easy for a first time roll maker.  I used the bread machine and followed all the directions exactly.  The only slight modification I made was just to put honey butter in place of regular butter.  That was just because I was wanting some extra sweetness.  The rolls would have been fine without it.  Personally the thing I loved about this recipe was that when the dough came out of the machine (after following the recipe exactly) it was extremely easy to work with.  Thanks for this recipe...it is a new staple in my house.  We live in china and getting rolls is impossible so this recipe helped.  I also would like to note I made them in a toaster oven because that is all I have and it still turned out great.  I think this is a good fool proof mixture of ingredients!

**A second review** this dough freezes extremely well also and is easily put directly into the oven for quick fresh rolls.  I take the dough out of the breadmaker, immediately form the rolls and freeze.  I keep a large bag of the frozen dough balls in my freezer and just pull out what I need for dinner.  I add a few more minutes cooking time for the frozen aspect of the dough.....absolutely perfect AND easy.  my favorite rolls recipe ever.  I use it several times a week.

I've made these many many times, and I didn't realize that I've never rated it.  This is a fantastic recipe.  Love the ease of using the machine to make the dough.  I've done pull-aparts with these as well as the crescent shape, and they always turn out soft and delicious, with a touch of sweet. userID:
3321070
Display Name:
Tammy Rene Benedict
isPro:

followersCount:
4

3
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1653570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe for dinner rolls. I made the dough in my breadmaker, and after one rise cycle took the dough out of the breadmaker, and punched it down--made rolls/balls. I'm not sure how some of the reviewers got fewer rolls than the recipe calls for, unless you made very large rolls. Also, about the flour--someone mentioned this, but I'll mention it again 1. The amount of flour in roll recipes is somewhat variable, which should be adjusted to your taste, and climate, and "feel" of the dough. I added a little bit once I saw that the dough was in need of it, after the machine kneaded it for 10 minutes or so  2. I always use breadflour for my breads/rolls with yeast. It's just a preference I think.  Using an egg wash increases the aesthetic of the rolls IMO, but it's up to your own preference.   overall, these are the BEST rolls I've ever made--and the closest I believe I'll ever come to my husband's grandmother's yeast rolls (she took that recipe to her grave, but wow!)..and this is pretty close. The only modification I did was to melt 2T of Honey into the butter, and I used 2.5tsp of bread machine yeast.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Rolls were MOST EXCELLENT!  Texture A+, taste A+.  I make all my own bread and rolls and don't use a bread machine, food processor or Kitchen Aid mixer, I enjoy kneading dough.  As someone who makes a lot of yeast doughs as a tip to others who don't.  The flour in a recipe is just an estimate.  Humidity and other variables dictate how much you will need.  Also, remember that salt and sugar should be carefully measured.  Salt is absolutely necessary but one of it's functions is to inhibit rising.  Always allow plenty of time when making bread or rolls and remeber a dough that rises slowly that it gives a wonderful taste to the finished product.

text:
I LOVE this recipe. However I started making these roles about an hour before dinner so I didn't let them rise as long as they should. I initially let them rise for about 30 mins, punched a hole in the middle, divided into 8 big rolls, let those rise for about 20 mins...and baked at 350 for about 10 mins. PARFAIT. Its comforting to know I dont need to let them rise for as long and they will still turn out great.

text:
My family loves this yummy bread recipe!  I make it every week on the dough setting in my bread machine as our sandwich loaf (I don't even bother to get out the recipe any more; I've got it memorized!).  Some weeks I make it with 2 1/2 c. all-purpose flour and 1 1/4 c. whole wheat flour, and other weeks I make it as written with just all-purpose flour.  I always bake it in the oven at 400 degrees after letting it rise 1 hour in the greased loaf pans (it makes 1 large loaf and 1 mini loaf, which we use for toast).  Brush the tops of the loaves with melted butter before and after baking:  YUM!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2781780.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were DELICIOUS!  I, too, used my KitchenAid mixer.  I mixed the milk and water together, and microwaved it for 1 minute.  I added the yeast to this mixture, and let it dissolve.  Next, I added the sugar.  Then, I added the remainder of the ingredients, except for the flour, and mixed them together.  Finally, I added the flour 1/2 a cup at a time and continued to stir.  When a ball was formed, I turned the mixer to the kneading cycle, and I kneaded for about 3-5 minutes.  I placed the dough into a greased bowl, turning once to cover the entire dough.  I let this raise for an hour.  I then punched down the dough, cut into two sections, and proceeded as initial directions stated.    These rolls came out absolutely delicious.  My husband said he could have these every night of the week.

text:
These were wonderful fresh out of the oven! I made them with honey cinnamon butter and they were identical to Texas road house! Delicious! 
Update: I didn't use a bread machine, but I used my kitchen ad dough hook to knead for about 10 minutes. They turned out so good! You need to knead the dough sufficiently to form enought gluten to support the air bubbles made by the yeast so you have soft fluffy rolls. Trust me. They will be perfect! 
I also baked mine so that each roll touched one another once the were risen and baked. They were the most beautiful rolls I've ever made.

These have such a good taste that you can't quit eating them! My only complaint is that mine were really dense. I am positive that a third time would result in perfect rolls!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Probably the best rolls I've ever tasted.  This will become my main roll recipe from now on.  Don't have a breadmaker, so I followed the instructions from the 1st reviewer K. Praper.  I don't have a kitchenaid, so I just used a whisk to get the butter and the first few scoops of flour incorporated (see her instructions).  Then I used a regular spatula and stirred everything together.  The baking part turned out great, too.  Turn oven to 350 and bake on the bottom rack for 10 minutes.  Then put on the middle rack and bake for 2 more minutes.  They cook evenly and have a nice light golden color.  Delicious!

text:
Perfect! 1 and 3 yr old loved them, hubby ate 3! I think I will make them in my Kitchen Aid next time so I can better monitor the consistency of the dough. I could tell my bread machine wasn't getting all the flour incorporated while it was kneading, so my dough was sticky after the initial rising. I added more flour as I shaped the rolls and they were fine. Will try half wheat flour next time too.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these with Christmas dinner, and they were my favorite part of the meal!  I used only 3 1/2 tablespoons of butter in the dough and didn't add any on top (didn't roll them up, either, just dropped 7 balls in 3 sprayed pie pans, making 21 rolls).  I also used 1 cup whole wheat flour in place of 1 cup of the white flour.  Oh, and for the pan I wanted to serve immediately, I only let it rise for 30 minutes after it came out of the bread machine (had them in the oven on "Warm") and I didn't notice much of a difference between them and the ones that rose for an hour.  SOOO good, especially warm!  Will definitely make this again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Although I am an experienced cook, this was the first time I ever tried yeast rolls. I followed the directions carefully even to the water temp. I put 1 teas. sugar in with my yeast. I used less sugar as some did, but I wish I had left it in. I used bread flour and sifted well before I added flour a little at a time, reserving part to work in as I kneaded. (About ½ cup) Kneaded about 8 min. with remaining flour, and let the dough rise in warm place about 2 hrs. Shaped dough into balls lightly handling and placed in pan. Let them rise until well doubled about 1 hr. They were delicious! A little dense, but still a big improvement over store bought. But next time I will add all the sugar, and play with the receipe. I will definitely make these rolls again.

text:
Wow!  Everything that could go wrong DID go wrong when I made this rolls, but they still turned out great! My bread machine wasn't working, so I had to remove the partially made dough and finish it in my kitchen aid mixer with the dough hook.  Then, when I rolled out the dough it kept sticking to the  cutting board, so I had to add a lot of flour which I knew was a no no but I just had to!  The rolls still turned out amazingly well and everyone loved them.  I will make these the good old fashioned way next time, though!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I altered this recipe by adding a half a cup of cooked, plain, mashed potatoes and increasing the sugar by 1/4 cup. Flour will also increse by 2 - 3 cups. This was done for a serving size of 16.  After they rose, I mashed them down and rolled them out.  I cut them into circles and placed them in the pan and let them rise again.  I then baked them in a 375 oven for about 15 minutes. They came out fantastic.  Much thanks to the originator.

text:
Absolutely perfect!!! I made half as directed and the other half as cinnamon rolls which are in the fridge for tomorow morning. I did not have a machine so I did the following: Proof yeast in the water and sugar. Heat milk and butter. Add egg. Add yeast mixture and then salt. Mix in flour. (I had to use more that the recipe called for but it is very humid today) kneeaded for about ten minutes and then set to rise. This is for sure going in my cookbook!!!

text:
I am torn on how many stars to rate this.  I made the dough and had to add more flour than called for and still yet the dough was sticky. (it rained that day but still, have never had to add that much extra before on a rainy day)  When I rolled it out to make the cinnamon rolls the dough easily tore. It was very delicate.  Now I have made many, many cinnamon rolls before.  I only switched to this recipe because my parents have a bread machine and my recipe was too big, so I know how the dough normally feels.   Even after all that my parents and my brother loved the rolls.  (I live far away and don't get to visit but once every year and a half so this is the first time I made rolls for them)  But having my own recipe to compare them too, I don't think they match up, that's why only 4 stars.

text:
If I could give this recipe a 10, I would! I have never been so successful w/ yeast before! I followed K Praper's review (to mix by hand b/c I don't have a bread machine). Except I threw in the salt while proofing the yeast. After fooling with the dough for too long I made 16 rolls, I thought they would come out too little (probably from trying to decide it I wanted to make crescents or rolls), but they didn't. The taste reminds me of the Hawaiian rolls you can buy. Don't be alarmed if they come out of the oven pale, they don't brown much unless you use egg wash. I will be making this very often. Thank you so much!!

Display Name:
GJEREDDIA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these for an Easter get-together this weekend, and everyone loved them! I always make the rolls, and I wanted to try something different this year. They were a big hit. No bread machine, but I always use the method on the Rapid-Rise yeast packages when I make bread, which is very simple, and it worked beautifully. Mix all your dry ingredients. Heat the liquids to 125-130 (nuke in microwave around 2 min.). I tempered the eggs and added the liquids and eggs to the dry mixture, kneaded in my Kitchen Aid mixer (had to add some extra flour so that it wasn't so sticky), let it rest 10 min. (replaces first rise) and shaped into crescent rolls. Let rise and bake. They were light and buttery and puffed much more than my standard recipe. Loved them! Doubled the receipe but wished I had made more.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these rolls today. I am on a low sodium diet and found the refrigerated rolls from the supermarket to be too high in sodium. 

Having said this, I was looking for a nice, soft buttery dinner roll to make from scratch. I followed the recipe exactly in my bread machine, except I accidentally used 1/4 cup butter instead of 1/3 cup. 

The dough came out extremely sticky. I had to add a lot of extra flour to make it managable. I also looked at the "most helpful" reviews and decided to make clover style rolls using a muffin  pan. I brushed the tops with butter before baking and again after they were cooked.

These were just ok, but nothing to write home about. My sons did not care for them at all. Hubby ate them with tons of butter and gravy from the chicken we had for dinner. The dogs loved the leftovers though :-). 

I'll try the recipe one more time and will follow the directions exactly making them into crescent rolls to be fair.  There must be some reason mostly everyone raved about them on this site.

text:
The taste of these rolls were very good.  I love just about any kind of homemade bread but I had a bit of trouble with the whole process.  I tried to make these in the bread machine and when I took out the dough, I kind of punched it down, and kneaded it just for a few seconds then I pulled apart a bit at a time to make small round rolls.  I let them sit for quite a while as I left for my sons basketball game and came home to no difference in rise.  so, I put them in a 200 degree oven until they rose a bit, then as I was heating the oven to 400, most of them kind of fell.  I baked as instructed and put an egg wash on some.  The taste was great but the appearance was not what I was hoping for.  Next time I think I'll use the kitchen aid! Maybe my yeast is getting on the old side, not sure but wouldn't want to serve these to company as flat as they were!  Need to keep practicing at my baking skills that's for sure.

userID:
1599685
Display Name:
Christine James
isPro:

5

0
madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:
164
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/689608.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE: I used this dough (made in a bread machine) as a base for sticky buns.Roll as for cinnamon rolls and cut into 16 pcs. In two 9" cake pans, smear with this mixture: Beat together the following ingredients 1/2 cup granulated sugar
1/2 firmly packed brown sugar
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 pound (2 sticks) unsalted butter at room temperature
1/2 cup light corn syrup (didn’t have light corn syrup, used half honey and half dark corn syrup, was great)
1 tsp pure vanilla extract
Divide in half and smear into pans.
Let rise(or refrigerate overnight, covered with plastic wrap) until doubled in size. Bake about 20 minutes, until rolls are clearly done (not doughy) when you pull two rolls gently apart.
 Was great! This is a great recipe, I use it for dinner rolls, bread or "pocket sandwiches" with meat fillings. It has a rich flavor and is easy to work with.

text:
The recipe is so easy, my 12-year-old made these rolls for Thanksgiving.  We substituted 2 cups of whole wheat flour and used baking Splenda instead of the regular sugar.  Also watch the rolls as they bake, because we had to reduce the baking time to prevent burning.  They were very tasty and none of the kids noticed that we had used whole wheat flour.
